fields.content: Mark Burgin discussed "inductive" types of these things in an article that treats their process of generating "words" as closely resembling the task of calculating a real number to a desired precision. The Kolmogorov complexity of an input is formally defined as the simplest number of states used to encode that input in these models, which are formally defined with a 7-tuple. Treating these things as black boxes, or "oracles", is often done in proofs that make use of polynomial-time reductions. The namesake of these things determined that asking if they halt is undecidable. A head that reads and writes bits on an infinite tape is one component of, for 10 points, what entities that closely model computers, and which are named for a British computer scientist?

fields.content: This model functions as a single-stack pushdown automaton offering greater flexibility by not adhering to the last-in-first-out requirement. Associated with an aspect of problem 10 proposed by David Hilbert in 1900, it remained vaguely defined for nearly 30 years. Within formal language theory, it can enumerate subsets of valid strings from an alphabet. An algorithm that reads n numbers and computes 2 to the power of 2 to the power of n by repeated squaring runs in polynomial time in the Arithmetic model, though this efficiency does not extend to this model. For 10 points, name this theoretical construct pivotal in the study of computability and described by an eponymous mathematician.
clue_list: This model functions as a single-stack pushdown automaton offering greater flexibility by not adhering to the last-in-first-out requirement.
Associated with an aspect of problem 10 proposed by David Hilbert in 1900, it remained vaguely defined for nearly 30 years.
Within formal language theory, it can enumerate subsets of valid strings from an alphabet.

wiki_sents: A Turing machine is equivalent to a single-stack pushdown automaton (PDA) that has been made more flexible and concise by relaxing the last-in-first-out (LIFO) requirement of its stack.
With regard to Hilbert's problems posed by the famous mathematician David Hilbert in 1900, an aspect of problem #10 had been floating about for almost 30 years before it was framed precisely.
The algorithm that reads n numbers and then computes 2^{2^n} by repeated squaring runs in polynomial time in the Arithmetic model, but not in the Turing model.
In the context of formal language theory, a Turing machine (automaton) is capable of enumerating some arbitrary subset of valid strings of an alphabet.

In the arithmetic model, every basic arithmetic operation on real numbers (addition, subtraction, multiplication and division) can be done in a single step, whereas in the Turing model the run-time of each arithmetic operation depends on the length of the operands.
fields.answer: Turing machines [prompt on machines or abstract machines or abstract computers] <Jose>

fields.content: Although metal versions of this instrument were made in the past, major manufacturers have not produced them since 1889. Double and triple tonguing, flutter tonguing, multiphonics, quarter-tones, and singing are all techniques used in Bruno Bartolozzi's "Concertazioni" for this instrument. In the 1960s, Giles Brindley developed the "logical bassoon," which aimed to improve intonation and evenness of tone through an electrically activated mechanism that enabled complex key combinations. Many companies and individuals offer pre-made reeds for this instrument, but players often need to make adjustments to suit their particular playing style. The dulcian, which was not immediately supplanted, continued to be used well into the 18th century by Bach and others; repertoire from that period generally does not exceed the smaller compass of this instrument. Depending on the hardness, the profile of the cane, and the needs of the player, other adjustments with the reed knife may be necessary when playing this instrument. For 10 points, name this woodwind instrument whose total sounding length is longer due to its tube being doubled back on itself.

With regards to commercially made reeds, many companies and individuals offer pre-made reeds for sale, but players often find that such reeds still require adjustments to suit their particular playing style.
Other adjustments with the reed knife may be necessary, depending on the hardness, the profile of the cane, and the requirements of the player.

The dulcian was not immediately supplanted, but continued to be used well into the 18th century by Bach and others; and, presumably for reasons of interchangeability, repertoire from this time is very unlikely to go beyond the smaller compass of the dulcian.
The overall height of the bassoon stretches to tall, but the total sounding length is considering that the tube is doubled back on itself.

fields.content: This composer, who had a long friendship with Erich Katz and influenced Katz's compositions, wrote Trauermusik for solo viola and string orchestra in tribute to George V while preparing for the London premiere of Der Schwanendreher, a viola concerto. He premiered it the same evening he heard the news of the king's death. His philosophy encompassed creating melodies that do not clearly outline major or minor triads and advocated a unique system for understanding and analyzing harmonic structures, claiming its broader reach beyond the traditional Roman numeral approach tied to diatonic scales. This advocate of Gebrauchsmusik, compositions intended for social or political purposes and occasionally playable by amateurs, experienced fluctuating favor with the Nazis throughout the 1930s. For 10 points, name this German composer.
clue_list: This composer, who had a long friendship with Erich Katz and influenced Katz's compositions, wrote Trauermusik for solo viola and string orchestra in tribute to George V while preparing for the London premiere of Der Schwanendreher, a viola concerto.
He premiered it the same evening he heard the news of the king's death.

For 10 points, name this German composer.
wiki_sents: Hindemith had a long friendship with Erich Katz, whose compositions were influenced by him.Davenport 1970, p. 43.

He was preparing the London premiere of his viola concerto Der Schwanendreher when he heard news of the death of George V. He quickly wrote Trauermusik for solo viola and string orchestra in tribute to the late king, and the premiere was given that same evening, the day after the king's death.
His philosophy also encompassed melody—he strove for melodies that do not clearly outline major or minor triads.

He also advocated this system as a means of understanding and analyzing the harmonic structure of other music, claiming that it has a broader reach than the traditional Roman numeral approach to chords (an approach strongly tied to diatonic scales).
Hindemith wrote Gebrauchsmusik (Music for Use)—compositions intended to have a social or political purpose and sometimes written to be played by amateurs.
The controversy around his work continued throughout the thirties, with Hindemith falling in and out of favour with the Nazis.

fields.content: Wilhelm Grimm's study about the "The Legend of" this figure claims his chief distinguishing feature is a solar symbol. Achaemenides, the son of Adamastus, was abandoned when his leader was trying to escape this figure. A son of Faunus killed by this mythical figure became a river in Sicily. Apollodorus claims that a hero employed wine from Maron in a plot to maim this son of the nymph Thoösa and Poseidon. This man jealously crushed Acis with a boulder due to his desire for the nymph Galatea. A hero who claimed he was "outis" , or "no one", escaped from this figure's cave riding on the underbelly of a sheep after using a sharpened stake to blind him. fields.content: One such story from Georgia, in the Caucasus, describes several brothers held prisoner by a giant one-eyed shepherd called "One-eye," similar to this monster. In the morning, the shepherd lets the sheep out to graze, feeling their backs to ensure the men are not escaping. The Flemish artist Jacob Jordaens depicted Odysseus escaping from the cave of this Sicilian giant in a 1635 work, while other artists chose the scene of him casting boulders at the escaping ship. A sculpture by Corneille Van Clève from 1681 represents this figure seated, holding pipes in a lowered hand. The poet declares that where this creature had failed, Bion's greater artistry had won Galatea's heart, drawing her from the sea to tend his herds. Terrified, Galatea dives into the ocean as this Sicilian giant wrenches off a piece of the mountain and crushes Acis with it. For 10 points, name this Sicilian giant who is often depicted with an empty eye socket and a damaged eye located in the middle of the forehead.

In the morning, the blind Cyclops lets the sheep out to graze, feeling their backs to ensure that the men are not escaping.
Corneille Van Clève (1681) represents a seated Polyphemus in his sculpture, except that in his version it is pipes that the giant holds in his lowered hand.
Where Polyphemus had failed, the poet declares, Bion's greater artistry had won Galatea's heart, drawing her from the sea to tend his herds.

Of the European painters of the subject, the Flemish Jacob Jordaens depicted Odysseus escaping from the cave of Polyphemus in 1635 (see gallery below) and others chose the dramatic scene of the giant casting boulders at the escaping ship.
Galatea, terrified, dives into the ocean, while the Cyclops wrenches off a piece of the mountain and crushes Acis with it.
Polyphemus is portrayed, as it often happens, with two empty eye sockets and his damaged eye located in the middle on his forehead.

fields.content: In one text, a character escaped this figure by holding on to the belly of a ram named Phaëlis. This character's habitation was described in exquisite detail, including its door made of a gigantic rock, by Theocritus. He laments his infatuation with the sea-nymph Galatea in a series of Idylls. In one work, this being is depicted as a shepherd who consumes several of Odysseus' men. Eventually, Odysseus tricks him by claiming his name is "Nobody," which facilitates a daring escape. His eye is gouged out by a sharpened olivewood stake. For 10 points, name this Cyclops encountered by Odysseus in Homer's Odyssey.

fields.content: Mithraic temples often included a mysterious nude snake-entwined figure holding two keys who had the head of one of these animals. A knight wins back his wife Laudine after rescuing one of these creatures from a dragon and befriending it. After killing an asura while in the form of a boar, Vishnu killed the asura's elder brother Hiranyakashipu by taking a form that was half-man, half one of these creatures. Yvain was known as the "Knight of" this animal, while the avatar Narasimha had the head of one. In a Greek folktale, one of them hiding in a cave becomes friendly after Androcles pulls a thorn from its paw. A creature with the body of one of these animals kills itself after Oedipus provides the answer "man" to its riddle. For 10 points, the Sphinx had the body of what large feline?

fields.content: In the Republic of the Congo, Odzala-Kokoua National Park was a stronghold for these animals in the 1990s. In Cameroon's Waza National Park, between 14 and 21 of these animals persisted as of 2009. When a new male takes over a pride, adolescents of both sexes may be evicted. Historically, they were hunted by individuals, but elders now discourage solo hunts due to reduced populations. Although they do not influence the behavior of leopards, both are active around the same time of day. By 2014, no individuals were recorded in the protected area, making them locally extinct. For 10 points, name this animal that assumes specific roles in the pride, with slower-moving individuals providing other valuable services to the group.
clue_list: In the Republic of the Congo, Odzala-Kokoua National Park was a stronghold for these animals in the 1990s.
In Cameroon's Waza National Park, between 14 and 21 of these animals persisted as of 2009.
When a new male takes over a pride, adolescents of both sexes may be evicted.

For 10 points, name this animal that assumes specific roles in the pride, with slower-moving individuals providing other valuable services to the group.
wiki_sents: In the Republic of the Congo, Odzala-Kokoua National Park was considered a lion stronghold in the 1990s.
A population occurs in Cameroon's Waza National Park, where between approximately 14 and 21 animals persisted as of 2009.
When a new male lion takes over a pride, adolescents both male and female may be evicted.Scott, p. 68.
Historically, lions were hunted by individuals, however, due to reduced lion populations, elders discourage solo lion hunts.

Leopards, by contrast, do not appear to be motivated by an avoidance of lions, as they use heavy vegetation regardless of whether lions are present in an area and both cats are active around the same time of day.
By 2014, no lions were recorded in the protected area so the population is considered locally extinct.
Lions tend to assume specific roles in the pride; slower-moving individuals may provide other valuable services to the group.

fields.content: In a poem by Rainer Maria Rilke, this animal is described as pacing back and forth inside a narrow cage, "in cramped circles, over and over, the movement of its powerful soft strides." A mythological figure must capture one as his first labor, signifying courage and royalty. In one of Aesop's fables, a character of this species spares a mouse that later returns the favor. In Greek mythology, Heracles is famously tasked with defeating a particularly invulnerable one of these creatures from Nemea. The fairy tale collection "The Wizard of Oz" features a character embodying this animal who seeks courage. This animal's roar can be heard up to five miles away, underscoring its role as King of the Jungle. fields.content: A popular conspiracy theory held by tax protesters is that some parties in court cases do not actually exist since they are identified exclusively through the use of this technique. Styles that do not use this technique named "snake" and "kebab" are more commonly used in Python and Lisp than a style named "camel" that uses this technique in variable names. All five instances of the line "hurry up please its time" are written using entirely this technique in T. S. Eliot's The Waste Land. Its use is mandated for German nouns, while doing it to the English word "polish" changes its pronunciation and meaning. Much of e. e. cummings's poetry eschews both punctuation and, for 10 points, what typographical technique in which lower case letters are replaced by upper case ones?

fields.content: This process is addressed in Danish, where Æ/æ is considered a distinct letter rather than a typographic ligature, and in Icelandic, it holds a similar distinction. In Welsh, Ll is treated as a single letter and Ff corresponds to the English F, while Welsh F corresponds to the English V. This writing practice is associated with respect by some speakers of Eastern Slavic languages and is also used to decapitalize proper nouns to show disrespect. It is increasingly evident in some trademarks and company names that begin with a lowercase letter. Ancient Greek texts and, to a lesser extent, Latin texts in most modern editions do not apply this typographical practice to the first word of a sentence. In other languages, such as the Romance languages, this orthographic feature is typically applied only to the first word and proper names. For 10 points, name this linguistic convention often applied to defined terms that refer to a specific entity, such as "tenant" and "lessor."
clue_list: This process is addressed in Danish, where Æ/æ is considered a distinct letter rather than a typographic ligature, and in Icelandic, it holds a similar distinction.
In Welsh, Ll is treated as a single letter and Ff corresponds to the English F, while Welsh F corresponds to the English V.
This writing practice is associated with respect by some speakers of Eastern Slavic languages and is also used to decapitalize proper nouns to show disrespect.
It is increasingly evident in some trademarks and company names that begin with a lowercase letter.
Ancient Greek texts and, to a lesser extent, Latin texts in most modern editions do not apply this typographical practice to the first word of a sentence.
In other languages, such as the Romance languages, this orthographic feature is typically applied only to the first word and proper names.
For 10 points, name this linguistic convention often applied to defined terms that refer to a specific entity, such as "tenant" and "lessor."
wiki_sents: Examples with ligature include in Danish, where Æ/æ is a completely separate letter rather than merely a typographic ligature (the same applies in Icelandic); examples with separate characters are in Welsh, where Ll is a single letter; and in Welsh where Ff is equivalent to English F (whereas Welsh F corresponds to English V).Lewis, H (ed) Collins-Spurrell Welsh Dictionary Collins UK 1977 p. 10.
Some speakers of Eastern Slavic languages associate capitalization with respect and decapitalize proper nouns to show disrespect.
The first word of a sentence is not capitalized in most modern editions of ancient Greek and, to a lesser extent, Latin texts.
Increasingly nowadays, some trademarks and company names start with a lowercase letter, and similar considerations apply.
In legal English, defined terms that refer to a specific entity, such as "Tenant" and "Lessor", are often capitalized.
In other languages, such as the Romance languages, only the first word and proper names are capitalized.
fields.answer: capitalization[accept word forms; accept descriptive answers like all capsor capitalized first letter; accept using upper casebefore "upper"] <Jose>

fields.content: A specific and now-outdated form of this phenomenon is known as "medial s," which was often seen in early printing centuries ago. The rules governing this phenomenon have varied greatly throughout history, including the principled use of uppercase and lowercase letters in Old German texts. Gregg Shorthand presents a unique case where this phenomenon is almost entirely absent. "Lower," "small," and "minuscule" forms opposed to "upper," "large," and "majuscule" forms pertain to this linguistic feature. In English orthography, the first letter of proper nouns adheres to this rule. Titles and headings often follow specific conventions of this phenomenon. For 10 points, identify this grammatical rule that dictates the use of uppercase and lowercase letters.

fields.content: A failed mission led by this man was completed 100 years later by Henry Worsley. Frank Hurley captured color photos of a mission led by this man that included an unexpected trip in the James Caird. Raymond Priestley suggested that "when you are in a hopeless situation," you should "get down on your knees and pray for" this explorer. Meteorologist Jameson Boyd Adams was the second-in-command on this man's Nimrod Expedition. He had a falling-out with Robert Falcon Scott after an aborted 1902 expedition. Later, he turned back 97 miles away from a destination that would soon be reached by Roald Amundsen. His crew got trapped on Elephant Island during the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition. For 10 points, name this polar explorer who saved the stranded crew of the Endurance.

fields.answer: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton <Bentley, History - European>

fields.content: A statue of this explorer by Charles Sargeant Jagger was unveiled at the Royal Geographical Society in 1932, although public memorials to him were relatively few. His first polar venture was as third officer on Captain Scott's Discovery Expedition from 1901 to 1904, where he set a new southern record by reaching latitude eighty-two degrees south but was sent home early due to health issues. After being refused a job, Welsh sailor Perce Blackborow stowed away on his ship and ended up working in the ship's galley. Official photographer Frank Hurley, who captured perilous shots during the expedition, gained later fame. In the Weddell Sea, conditions worsened until his ship Endurance became frozen in an ice floe on January 19, 1915. This Antarctic explorer later joined the ship Aurora to rescue the Ross Sea party, which had completed its depot-laying mission despite hardships. After Roald Amundsen ended the race to the South Pole in 1911, this explorer aimed for a trans-Antarctic crossing via the pole. For 10 points, name this explorer, who became a 20th-century role model for leadership in extreme circumstances.
clue_list: A statue of this explorer by Charles Sargeant Jagger was unveiled at the Royal Geographical Society in 1932, although public memorials to him were relatively few.

His first polar venture was as third officer on Captain Scott's Discovery Expedition from 1901 to 1904, where he set a new southern record by reaching latitude eighty-two degrees south but was sent home early due to health issues.
After being refused a job, Welsh sailor Perce Blackborow stowed away on his ship and ended up working in the ship's galley.
Official photographer Frank Hurley, who captured perilous shots during the expedition, gained later fame.

This Antarctic explorer later joined the ship Aurora to rescue the Ross Sea party, which had completed its depot-laying mission despite hardships.
After Roald Amundsen ended the race to the South Pole in 1911, this explorer aimed for a trans-Antarctic crossing via the pole.
For 10 points, name this explorer, who became a 20th-century role model for leadership in extreme circumstances.
wiki_sents: A statue of Shackleton designed by Charles Sargeant Jagger was unveiled at the Kensington headquarters of the RGS in 1932, but public memorials to him were relatively few.

Shackleton's first experience of the polar regions was as third officer on Captain Robert Falcon Scott's Discovery Expedition of 1901–1904, from which he was sent home early on health grounds, after he and his companions Scott and Edward Adrian Wilson set a new southern record by marching to latitude 82°S.

Perce Blackborow was a nineteen-year-old Welsh sailor who had stowed away on the ship after being refused a job; although angered by this, Shackleton realised it was too late to turn back by the time the situation was discovered, so Blackborow was allowed to join the crew and assigned to the ship's galley.
Of later independent fame was the expedition's official photographer Frank Hurley, known on this mission for his perilous shots.
Shackleton travelled there to join Aurora, and sailed with her to rescue the Ross Sea party which, despite many hardships, had successfully completed its depot-laying mission.
Deep in the Weddell Sea, conditions gradually grew worse until, on 19 January 1915, Endurance became frozen fast in an ice floe.
After the race to the South Pole ended in December 1911, with Roald Amundsen's conquest, Shackleton turned his attention to the crossing of Antarctica from sea to sea, via the pole.
Later in the 20th century, Shackleton was "rediscovered", and he became a role model for leadership in extreme circumstances.
fields.answer: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton <Bentley, History - European>
answer_accept: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton <Bentley, History - European>

fields.content: One of this explorer's early expeditions to Antarctica in 1902 included a navigation task that compelled his party to march on rudimentary wood sleds. During his time on another expedition, this leader suffered a major setback after his ship became trapped in the Weddell Sea ice, ultimately leading to its destruction. This failure resulted in an arduous trek to Elephant Island followed by a legendary open-boat journey to South Georgia Island. His ventures to the Antarctic were marked by an endeavor to reach the South Pole prior to Amundsen's success. Following the ill-fated Endurance expedition, he returned to Antarctic exploration despite the economic turmoil post-World War I. Renowned for his leadership and survival skills, he adeptly managed his crew's morale during dire circumstances. His first major attempt aimed to traverse Antarctica from the Weddell Sea to the Ross Sea. Who is this explorer?
clue_list: One of this explorer's early expeditions to Antarctica in 1902 included a navigation task that compelled his party to march on rudimentary wood sleds.

Renowned for his leadership and survival skills, he adeptly managed his crew's morale during dire circumstances.
His first major attempt aimed to traverse Antarctica from the Weddell Sea to the Ross Sea.
Who is this explorer?
fields.answer: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton <Bentley, History - European>
answer_accept: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton <Bentley, History - European>

fields.content: An unsolved generalization of this result concerns the formation of "minors" by contractions, and is the Hadwiger conjecture. Heinrich Tietze extended this result to non-orientable surfaces. The first proof of this theorem was done at the University of Illinois, and relied on creating an "unavoidable set" of configurations and a "reducible configuration" to show that a certain counterexample was not possible. The 1976 proof of this theorem by Kenneth Appel and Wolfgang Haken was the first major proof to use a computer. This result does not hold for non-planar graphs, which requires at least one more hue to hold. For 10 points, name this theorem from "map" theory.

fields.content: Peer review over several years was necessary for verifying the volume describing the unavoidable configuration set related to this theorem. Despite its motivation from coloring political maps, this theorem is not of particular interest to cartographers. Some mathematical folklore suggests that Möbius originated the conjecture related to this theorem, but this idea appears erroneous. In 1996, Neil Robertson, Daniel P. Sanders, Paul Seymour, and Robin Thomas created a quadratic-time algorithm requiring only "big O" of "n squared" time, thereby improving a quartic-time algorithm based on the proof by Appel and Haken. It suffices to prove this theorem for triangulated graphs to prove it for all planar graphs. For 10 points, name this theorem that states that any planar graph can be colored with a maximum of four colors such that no two adjacent vertices share the same color.

Szilassi polyhedron 3D model.svg|Interactive Szilassi polyhedron model with each of 7 faces adjacent to every other – in , move the mouse to rotate it Visual proof mutually touching solids.svg|Proof without words that the number of colours needed is unbounded in three or more dimensions For graphs whose vertices are represented as pairs of points on two distinct surfaces, with edges drawn as non-crossing curves on one of the two surfaces, the chromatic number can be at least 9 and is at most 12, but more precise bounds are not known; this is Gerhard Ringel's Earth–Moon problem.
As far as is known,There is some mathematical folk-lore that Möbius originated the four-color conjecture, but this notion seems to be erroneous.

In 1996, Neil Robertson, Daniel P. Sanders, Paul Seymour, and Robin Thomas created a quadratic-time algorithm (requiring only O(n2) time, where n is the number of vertices), improving on a quartic-time algorithm based on Appel and Haken's proof.
So it suffices to prove the four color theorem for triangulated graphs to prove it for all planar graphs, and without loss of generality we assume the graph is triangulated.

fields.content: In 1976, this mathematical concept was proven using roughly 2000 hours of computer time and 1200 lines of code written by Kenneth Appel and Wolfgang Haken. The general concept of this theorem was first conjectured by the English mathematician Francis Guthrie in 1852. The proof of this theorem famously caused controversy because it was one of the first to rely heavily on computer assistance. This theorem posits that a certain maximal number of colors is necessary to fill regions on a map such that no two adjacent regions share the same color. The problem this theorem addresses is a classic example in the field of graph theory. For 10 points, name this theorem.

fields.content: Principal sources for the story behind this painting include sections 24–26 of the first book of Livy and book 3 of Dionysius's Roman Antiquities. Jacques-Louis David originally intended to depict a scene where the surviving Horatius raises his sword with his sister lying dead, and a drawing of this survives. The final composition, however, shows three brothers pledging to fight for Rome, illustrating a tension between personal and civic duty. This painting, exemplifying the values of the Age of Enlightenment and neoclassical idealism, reflects a growing trend towards loyalty to the state as the French Revolution approached. Promoting civic duty over personal ties, the artwork tells a morally uplifting story. For 10 points, name this painting that employs straight lines to symbolize strength in the swords, two of which are curved while one is straight, by Jacques-Louis David.

Originally David had intended to depict this episode, and a drawing survives showing the surviving Horatius raising his sword, with his sister lying dead.
As the French Revolution approached, paintings increasingly referred to loyalty to the state rather than the family or the church.
That it depicts a morally uplifting story, promoting civic duty over the personal, reflects the values of the Age of Enlightenment and neoclassical idealism.

The use of straight lines to depict strength is also demonstrated in the swords, two of which are curved while one is straight, perhaps foreshadowing that only one brother would survive the encounter.
Ultimately, David's picture manifests a progressive outlook, deeply influenced by Enlightenment ideas, that eventually contributed to the overthrow of the monarchy.

fields.content: For a one-electron system, the von Weizsäcker functional can express this quantity as \ \cdot \nabla \rho }{ \rho } d^3r \), given an electron density rho of r. However, the exact N-electron version of this quantity, in the context of density functional theory, only requires the electron density and not the wavefunction. wiki_sents: Given an electron density \rho(\mathbf{r}), the exact N-electron kinetic energy functional is unknown; however, for the specific case of a 1-electron system, the kinetic energy can be written as : T[\rho] = \frac{1}{8} \int \frac{ \nabla \rho(\mathbf{r}) \cdot \nabla \rho(\mathbf{r}) }{ \rho(\mathbf{r}) } d^3r where T[\rho] is known as the von Weizsäcker kinetic energy functional.
The density functional formalism of quantum mechanics requires knowledge of the electron density only, i.e., it formally does not require knowledge of the wavefunction.
Energy occurs in many forms, including chemical energy, thermal energy, electromagnetic radiation, gravitational energy, electric energy, elastic energy, nuclear energy, and rest energy.
In any different frame of reference, there is additional kinetic energy corresponding to the total mass moving at the speed of the center of mass.
For example, a cyclist uses chemical energy provided by food to accelerate a bicycle to a chosen speed.
Since the bicycle lost some of its energy to friction, it never regains all of its speed without additional pedaling.

Before sculpting this statue, Michelangelo engaged in extensive preparatory work, including sketches, drawings, and small-scale terracotta or wax models. Michelangelo eschewed the use of flat chisels and instead used toothed chisels to achieve a state of non finito. fields.content: A. J. R. Prentice theorized that this entity formed as a result of the shedding of systems of rings and tori of gas. This entity is treated as a dynamical system that evolves over time in the Nice model. Pierre-Simon Laplace proposed that this structure formed after a giant molecular cloud collapsed, creating a "disk" from which this structure's constituents formed. The Hill sphere is often used to define the boundaries of this structure, which extends beyond both TNOs and Kuiper belt objects. fields.content: A composition gradient exists in this structure, created by heat and light pressure from the early Sun. Objects closer to the Sun are composed of elements with high melting points. The largest known centaur, 10199 Chariklo, has a diameter of about 250 kilometers and possesses a ring system. Most larger moons in this system orbit their planets prograde; Neptune's moon Triton orbits retrograde. Charon, the largest moon of Pluto, is sometimes described as part of a binary system with Pluto, as the two orbit a barycenter above their surfaces. fields.content: This thinker proposed a theory involving shifts in large caverns filled with hot gases, which, although inaccurate, represented one of the earliest systematic attempts to explain earthquakes in natural rather than supernatural terms. He needed to explain how we combine what is known as sensory knowledge with the other type of knowledge—that is, reasoned knowledge—these two being related but having very different processes.

Although reason has a "logical use" of simply drawing inferences from principles, in "The Transcendental Dialectic", Kant is concerned with its purportedly "real use" to arrive at conclusions by way of unchecked regressive syllogistic ratiocination.
The section of the Critique entitled "The transcendental aesthetic" introduces Kant's famous metaphysics of transcendental idealism.

fields.content: Following Villeré's intelligence report, Jackson led 2,131 men in a brief three-pronged assault on unsuspecting British troops resting in their camp on December 23rd in this battle. Admiral Cochrane believed the British soldiers would easily defeat Jackson's army, and he allegedly said that if the army did not succeed, his sailors would. An account by Latour states that battalions of Plauché, Daquin, Lacoste, along with three-quarters of the 44th US Infantry, did not fire at all. On the right, British soldiers sent the militia defenders into retreat and were close to breaching the defensive line, but the left side resulted in a setback for the British. Before this battle, there were no overwhelming American land victories against British Army units—successes were primarily due to naval ships and forts. Despite a British advantage in numbers, training, and experience, American forces achieved victory in just over thirty minutes. For 10 points, name this battle that led to the decline of the Federalist Party and the rise of the Whig Party in opposition to Andrew Jackson.

Admiral Cochrane believed that the veteran British soldiers would easily destroy Jackson's ramshackle army, and he allegedly said that if the army did not do it, his sailors would, and the meeting settled the method and place of the attack.Patterson, Benton Rain, pp.
The account by Latour states the battalions of Plauché, Daquin, Lacoste, along with three quarters of the 44th US Infantry did not fire at all.

On the right side of this offensive the British soldiers successfully sent the militia defenders into a retreating panic with their huge show of force and were just a few hundred yards from breaching the defensive line, but the left side of the reconnaissance-in-force turned into disaster for the British.

Before New Orleans the war was overall a bloody stalemate with not a single overwhelming land battle victory for the Americans against an elite British Army unit (Lake Erie, Plattsburgh, and Baltimore were won primarily due to naval ships and forts near lakes or the ocean).
Despite a British advantage in numbers, training, and experience, the American forces defeated a poorly executed assault in slightly more than 30 minutes.
The void left by the Federalist Party was replaced by the Whig Party (United States), which came into being in 1833, in opposition to Andrew Jackson, and his policies as President.

fields.content: Some scholars have suggested that this mythological figure, due to her associations with thread-spinning and winding, may have been a weaving goddess similar to Arachne. These scholars support their hypothesis by referencing the mytheme of the Hanged Nymph and an alternative translation of a passage from Tibullus' Sixth Elegy: "Delightful Bacchus at his mystery Forbids these words of woe." In Letitia Elizabeth Landon's poem from Ideal Likenesses, this mythological figure is described as "a lesson how inconstancy should be repaid again by like inconstancy." Kerenyi posited that a Linear B inscription from Knossos, reading, "to all the gods, honey… to the mistress of the labyrinth honey" in equal amounts, implied that the Mistress of the Labyrinth, this woman, was a Great Goddess. In Hesiod and most other versions, this figure was abandoned by Theseus on Naxos and later wedded by Dionysus. For 10 points, name this daughter of Minos who helped Theseus conquer the Minotaur.

In Letitia Elizabeth Landon's poem from Ideal Likenesses (1825), she sees her as "a lesson how inconstancy should be repaid again by like inconstancy".

Kerenyi explained that a Linear B inscription from Knossos "to all the gods, honey… [,] to the mistress of the labyrinth honey" in equal amounts, implied to him that the Mistress of the Labyrinth was a Great Goddess in her own right.
Because ancient Greek myths were orally transmitted, like other myths, that of Ariadne has many variations.
In Hesiod and in most other versions, Theseus abandoned Ariadne sleeping on Naxos, and Dionysus rediscovered and wedded her.

Minos put Ariadne in charge of the labyrinth where sacrifices were made as part of reparations either to Poseidon or Athena, depending on the version of the myth; later, she helped Theseus conquer the Minotaur and save the children from sacrifice.

fields.content: Two sons of this deity named Agreus and Nomios joined twelve more of his offspring in India to assist Dionysus. fields.content: This decade saw the American auto industry deal with issues like poor quality control, increasing competition from imports, and a tough economic climate. College rock emerged through a do-it-yourself underground music movement. Tim Berners-Lee invented a system during this period that became the foundation of the World Wide Web. Inspired by Flashdance, fashion trends included shoulder pads, jean jackets, leather pants, aviator jackets, jumpsuits, and skin-tight acid-washed jeans. The Shining, a well-known film from this decade, received mixed reviews and achieved moderate financial success. wiki_sents: The American auto industry began in the 1980s in a thoroughly grim situation, faced with poor quality control, rising import competition, and a severe economic downturn.
College rock caught on in the underground scene of the 1980s in a nationwide movement with a distinct D.I.Y approach.
The Shining although a popular film from 1980 decades later, it was initially met with mixed reviews from critics and even the author of the book, and was moderately successful financially.

Significant clothing trends of the 1980s include shoulder pads, jean jackets, leather pants, leather aviator jackets, jumpsuits, Members Only jackets, skin-tight acid-washed jeans, Izod Lacoste and "preppy" polo shirts, leggings and leg warmers (popularized in the film Flashdance), off-the-shoulder shirts, and cut sweatshirts (popularized in the same film).
In the coming years Berners-Lee developed the system which would later become the foundation of the World Wide Web.
International debt crisis in developing countries, reliance of these countries on aid from the International Monetary Fund.

fields.content: Introduced by Ludwig Boltzmann, the Boltzmann equation has been fundamental in understanding macroscopic transport processes. The matrix of kinetic coefficients \ must be symmetric according to the Onsager reciprocal relations and positive definite to ensure entropy growth. When porosity approaches zero, the molar flux in a porous medium approaches zero given a concentration gradient. The standard derivation of the activity for this phenomenon includes a normalization factor; at small concentrations, it is expressed as \) \), where \ is the standard concentration. The mobility of a particle in a fluid or gas, symbolized as \, can be calculated using the Einstein relation from kinetic theory. For 10 points, name this net mass movement that, at larger scales, gives way to convection in liquids and gases, known as diffusion.

wiki_sents: Ludwig Boltzmann, in the development of the atomistic backgrounds of the macroscopic transport processes, introduced the Boltzmann equation, which has served mathematics and physics with a source of transport process ideas and concerns for more than 140 years.S.
The matrix of the kinetic coefficients L_{ij} should be symmetric (Onsager reciprocal relations) and positive definite (for the entropy growth).
For example, as the porosity goes to zero, the molar flux in the porous medium goes to zero for a given concentration gradient.
The standard derivation of the activity includes a normalization factor and for small concentrations a = n/n^\ominus + o(n/n^\ominus), where n^\ominus is the standard concentration.
μ is the mobility of the particle in the fluid or gas, which can be calculated using the Einstein relation (kinetic theory).
On larger length scales, transport in liquids and gases is normally due to another transport phenomenon, convection.

fields.content: Between November 2015 and March 2016, a study by the Xitou Nature Education Area in Taiwan examined littering by tourists in relation to this concept. Chen and Risen criticized the free-choice paradigm as invalid in their study "How Choice Affects and Reflects Preferences: Revisiting the Free-choice Paradigm," arguing that the rank-choice-rank method is inaccurate for studying this concept. This term refers to the mental stress experienced when an individual holds two or more contradictory beliefs, attitudes, or values simultaneously. This concept induces a state of negative affect, motivating individuals to reconsider the behavior causing the psychological inconsistency to resolve the mental stress. One gap in research is the effect of this concept in cases where individuals hold unfavorable attitudes toward both options. wiki_sents: Between November 2015 and March 2016, a study by Xitou Nature Education Area in Taiwan examined littering of tourists.

In the study How Choice Affects and Reflects Preferences: Revisiting the Free-choice Paradigm (Chen, Risen, 2010) the researchers criticized the free-choice paradigm as invalid, because the rank-choice-rank method is inaccurate for the study of cognitive dissonance.

Cognitive dissonance produces a state of negative affect, which motivates the person to reconsider the causative behavior in order to resolve the psychological inconsistency that caused the mental stress.Jones, E. E., Gerard, H. B., 1967.
The idea is, choosing something that is in opposition to how you feel or believe in will increase cognitive dissonance.
What wasn't studied were the cognitive dissonance effects in cases where the person had unfavorable attitudes toward both candidates.

The BP uses cognitive dissonance to target ED, for example, social pressure from peers or not being satisfied with your appearance, to bring awareness and for a healthy and positive change, thoughts toward body image.

fields.content: In a study conducted by Festinger and Carlsmith, participants who were paid a small sum experienced a certain psychological phenomenon more intensely than those who were paid a larger sum. Another notable study associated with this concept involved participants completing boring tasks and then being asked to lie about the enjoyment of the tasks to another participant. This phenomenon can also be observed in Aesop's "The Fox and the Grapes" where rationalization of unattainable goals occurs. fields.content: During his lifetime, the philosophical ideas of this thinker were comparatively less influential outside of America. Alfred North Whitehead notes that the thought of this Idealist philosopher facilitated the emergence of Hume's and thus Kant's work. This Idealist philosopher proposed the theory of signs to explain motion and matter without reference to the "occult qualities" of force and gravity. According to this thinker, the nature of the world is approachable only through proper metaphysical speculation and reasoning. wiki_sents: Outside of America, during Berkeley's lifetime, his philosophical ideas were comparatively uninfluential.See: McCracken, Charles J. and Tipton, Ian, eds., Berkeley's Principles and Dialogues: Background Source Materials.
Berkeley's "thought made possible the work of Hume and thus Kant, notes Alfred North Whitehead".Cited from: Steinkraus, W. E. Berkeley, epistemology, and science // Idealistic Studies.
The nature of the world, according to Berkeley, is only approached through proper metaphysical speculation and reasoning.
He proposed his theory of signs as a means to explain motion and matter without reference to the "occult qualities" of force and gravity.

In 1709, Berkeley published his first major work, An Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision, in which he discussed the limitations of human vision and advanced the theory that the proper objects of sight are not material objects, but light and colour.See This foreshadowed his chief philosophical work, A Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge, in 1710, which, after its poor reception, he rewrote in dialogue form and published under the title Three Dialogues Between Hylas and Philonous in 1713.

fields.content: This philosopher’s early work includes a 1707 manuscript entitled "De Motu" that was later published posthumously. An analysis of his philosophical method appears in meticulous correspondence he held with John Percival and Samuel Johnson. He was appointed the Bishop of Cloyne, where he produced works like "Siris," which unexpectedly praises the benefits of tar-water. One of his major contributions criticized the notion of abstract ideas, setting the stage against the prevailing Cartesian dualism of his time. Among the world's 500 largest stock-market-listed companies by revenue in 2023, thirty-two are headquartered in this country, according to the Fortune Global 500 list.

Combined domestic and international travel and tourism directly contribute over 105.3 billion euros to this nation's GDP. The Congress of Vienna's decision to appoint the emperor of Austria as the permanent president reflected the assembly's rejection of Prussia's influence in this country.
In this nation, where LGBT rights are generally protected, same-sex marriage has been legal since 2017.
For 10 points, name this European country recognized as a significant power, holding the largest economy in Europe.
wiki_sents: The 2018 Michelin Guide awarded eleven restaurants in Germany three stars, giving the country a cumulative total of 300 stars.

The 16 national parks in Germany include the Jasmund National Park, the Vorpommern Lagoon Area National Park, the Müritz National Park, the Wadden Sea National Parks, the Harz National Park, the Hainich National Park, the Black Forest National Park, the Saxon Switzerland National Park, the Bavarian Forest National Park and the Berchtesgaden National Park.
Of the world's 500 largest stock-market-listed companies measured by revenue in 2023, the Fortune Global 500, 32 are headquartered in Germany.
Domestic and international travel and tourism combined directly contribute over €105.3 billion to German GDP.
The appointment of the emperor of Austria as the permanent president reflected the Congress's rejection of Prussia's rising influence.
Same-sex marriage has been legal in Germany since 2017, and LGBT rights are generally protected in the nation.
Germany has been described as a great power with a strong economy; it has the largest economy in Europe.
fields.answer: Germany [accept Deutschland, German Empire, Weimar Germany, or Nazi Germany] <Boyd, RMP - Philosophy>

fields.content: The "Romantic Road," a popular tourist route, passes through towns such as Rothenburg ob der Tauber in this country. A novel set in a city on the River Elbe in this country details the tragic life of a drummer boy named Oskar Matzerath. This nation’s role as the center of the Holy Roman Empire is depicted in works like Johann Wolfgang von Goethe’s "Faust." Under Chancellor Otto von Bismarck, this nation was unified in 1871 following the Franco-Prussian War. Konrad Adenauer was the first chancellor of this country following World War II. Festivals such as Oktoberfest highlight the cultural heritage of this nation. For 10 points, name this country.

fields.content: In 1962, McGill University professor F. R. Scott defended this novel from censorship before the Supreme Court of Canada. Jenny Turner argued in The Sexual Imagination from Acker to Zola: A Feminist Companion that this work broke "the taboo on explicit representations of sexual acts" in British and North American literature. Clifford Chatterley, who wants to modernize the mines, is depicted as out of touch with nature. This novel by D. H. Lawrence faced significant controversy regarding its content. Joan remarks that the pages "just fall open" to presumably the most provocative portions of this book. For 10 points, name this novel for which the Department of Customs and Excise lifted the ban in July 1965, along with Borstal Boy, Confessions of a Spent Youth, and Lolita.

Clifford wants to reinvigorate the mines with new technology and is out of touch with the natural world.
It is written by a man with a diseased mind and a soul so black that he would obscure even the darkness of hell!
It is spoken of in scandalous tones and Joan remarks that the pages 'just fall open' to presumably the most salacious portions of the book.
The ban by the Department of Customs and Excise on Lady Chatterley's Lover, along with three other books—Borstal Boy, Confessions of a Spent Youth, and Lolita—was lifted in July 1965.

fields.content: This man postulated working close to the Earth's surface and altering matter there or telling other people to do so as the two types of work. In another work this thinker criticized "Oriental despotisms" for their influence on thought. In that work, this man criticized the idea that the object of morals is not to make people happy. In addition to In Praise of Idleness, this thinker wrote about how a group "retards progress" because that organization relies on inventing allies in the sky. In another work, this man included a page-long proof of how "one plus one equals two" as part of an attempt to axiomatically prove mathematics with a collaborator. For 10 points, name this thinker who wrote the essay Why I am Not a Christian and who collaborated with Alfred Whitehead on Principia Mathematica.

fields.answer: Bertrand Arthur William Russell, 3rd Earl Russell <Boyd, RMP - Philosophy>

fields.content: In 1948, this thinker delivered the BBC Reith Lectures titled "Authority and the Individual." He participated in numerous broadcasts over the BBC, including The Brains Trust and the Third Programme. An advocate of population control, he generated controversy on 20 November 1948 during a public speech at Westminster School by suggesting a preemptive nuclear strike on the Soviet Union. In 1900, he published "Sur la logique des relations avec des applications à la théorie des séries." This philosopher achieved early acclaim with The Principles of Mathematics and supported the publication of Wittgenstein's Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus in 1922. For 10 points, name this philosopher.

For 10 points, name this philosopher.
wiki_sents: 1948, BBC Reith Lectures: Authority and the Individual A series of six radio lectures broadcast on the BBC Home Service in December 1948.
Russell participated in many broadcasts over the BBC, particularly The Brains Trust and for the Third Programme, on various topical and philosophical subjects.

Russell was also an advocate of population control: On 20 November 1948, in a public speech at Westminster School, addressing a gathering arranged by the New Commonwealth, Russell shocked some observers by suggesting that a preemptive nuclear strike on the Soviet Union was justified.
1900, Sur la logique des relations avec des applications à la théorie des séries, Rivista di matematica 7: 115–148.
This, along with the earlier The Principles of Mathematics, soon made Russell world-famous in his field.

This was a drain on Russell's energy, but Russell continued to be fascinated by him and encouraged his academic development, including the publication of Wittgenstein's Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus in 1922.
fields.answer: Bertrand Arthur William Russell, 3rd Earl Russell <Boyd, RMP - Philosophy>
answer_accept: Bertrand Arthur William Russell, 3rd Earl Russell <Boyd, RMP - Philosophy>

fields.content: One early work by this thinker includes a critique of the neo-Hegelian philosophy that dominated British academia at the time, titled *An Essay on the Foundations of Geometry*. This philosopher rejected the notion of "sense-data" in favor of "demonstrative knowledge" in his work *Our Knowledge of the External World*. With G. E. Moore, this philosopher co-authored *Principia Ethica*, which argued against the idea that moral propositions could be true or false. This individual famously collaborated with Alfred North Whitehead on a text meant to ground mathematics in logic, *Principia Mathematica*. His essay *Why I Am Not a Christian* sparked controversy by criticizing religious belief. For 10 points, name this 20th-century British philosopher and logician.

fields.content: In an eruption of violence against this group, mobs barbecued the slum residents of Block 32 with state-supplied kerosene. Repressive efforts like Operation Woodrose radicalized members of this group who blew up a Boeing 747 flying from Montreal in the deadliest airplane hijacking prior to 9/11. The quote "When a great tree falls, the earth shakes" was used to dismiss a wave of pogroms against this group. In 1984, Jarnail Bhindranwale led militants from this group's Khalistan movement in a protest blown up by tank shells in Operation Bluestar; afterward, two bodyguards from this group killed Indira Gandhi. For 10 points, name this religious minority in the Punjab that Hindu mobs identified by their turbans and uncut hair.

fields.content: According to 2019–20 estimates, this religious group has an average fertility rate of 1.6 children per woman, one of the lowest in the world. Known for its commitment to sarbat da bhala, which emphasizes the well-being of all, its members frequently engage in global humanitarian efforts. Although Bhangra is associated with Punjab, it is often linked to this group in popular perception. During the 1857 Indian mutiny, this community remained loyal to the British, leading to significant recruitment from Punjab into the British Indian Army during the subsequent ninety years of British colonial rule. For ten points, name this group that has the highest national proportion of its population in Canada at 2.1 percent, while the Punjab state in India has the largest proportion at 58 percent.

wiki_sents: Sikhs in the world have the lowest fertility rate of 1.6 children per women as per (2019–20) estimation research.
Sikhs strongly believe in the idea of sarbat da bhala () and are often seen on the frontline to provide humanitarian aid across the world.
Today, Canada has the largest national Sikh proportion (2.1%) in the world, while the Punjab state in India has the largest Sikh proportion (58%) amongst all administrative divisions in the world.
Punjabi Sikhs have championed these forms of expression worldwide, resulting in Sikh culture becoming linked to Bhangra (although "Bhangra is not a Sikh institution but a Punjabi one").
During the 1857 Indian mutiny, the Sikhs stayed loyal to the British, resulting in heavy recruitment from Punjab to the British Indian Army for the next 90 years of the British Raj in colonial India.

fields.content: Studies of this location led Clarence Dutton to propose that Earth's core must be partly liquid. In this region, the Vishnu, Brahma, and Rama schists are intruded by "Zoroaster granite," and those rocks define this region's namesake "supergroup." Gaps in the Tonto Group of sedimentary rocks in this region, which contains the Uinkaret volcanic field, led a 19th-century explorer to call the missing data the "Great Unconformity." The Tapeats Sandstone within this region suggests that during the Paleozoic it was home to a large ocean. The surveyor John Wesley Powell mapped this region, whose expansive geologic column is exposed due to erosion caused by the Colorado River flowing through it. For 10 points, name this region in Arizona.

fields.content: In a 2008 study, Victor Polyak examined caves near this geological feature and dated its origins to around seventeen million years ago. In 1851, Captain Joseph R. Walker traveled up the Colorado River, reaching a junction with the Virgin River, then continued east into Arizona along this landmark, making side trips. Increasing visitation has raised concerns about the sustainability of the water supply and the condition of the pipeline at this site. Almost all runoff from the North Rim flows toward it, while the South Rim runoff flows away, following the plateau's tilt. Around half of the Kaibab Plateau has high to very high vulnerability for the unconfined Coconino aquifer, and a fifth is vulnerable for the Redwall-Muav aquifer in this area. For ten points, name this Arizona landmark with geologic exposures ranging from the two-billion-year-old Vishnu Schist to the two-hundred-seventy-million-year-old Kaibab Limestone.

wiki_sents: In a 2008 study, Victor Polyak examined caves near the Grand Canyon and placed their origins about 17million years ago.

According to the San Francisco Herald, in a series of articles run in 1853, Captain Joseph R. Walker in January 1851 with his nephew James T. Walker and six men, traveled up the Colorado River to a point where it joined the Virgin River and continued east into Arizona, traveling along the Grand Canyon and making short exploratory side trips along the way.

Almost half of the Kaibab plateau's surface was associated with high to very high vulnerability of the unconfined Coconino aquifer (C-aquifer), while about a fifth of the Kaibab Plateau was estimated to be an area of high vulnerability for the Redwall-Muav aquifer (R-aquifer).
As water consumption continues to soar due to increasing visitation in the park, both the sustainability of the water supply and the condition of the pipeline are in question.

Almost all runoff from the North Rim (which also gets more rain and snow) flows toward the Grand Canyon, while much of the runoff on the plateau behind the South Rim flows away from the canyon (following the general tilt).
The major geologic exposures in the Grand Canyon range in age from the two-billion-year-old Vishnu Schist at the bottom of the Inner Gorge to the 270-million-year-old Kaibab Limestone on the Rim.

fields.content: In 1869, John Wesley Powell led the first recorded expedition through this site, which was famously described as a "vast wilderness." In 1903, President Theodore Roosevelt visited and called for its preservation as a national park. The Vishnu Schist and Zoroaster Granite are two of the oldest rock layers found in this landmark. The Hualapai, Havasupai, and Navajo tribes have historical ties to this natural wonder. Encompassed by a national park in Arizona, it receives nearly five million visitors annually. For 10 points, name this massive natural formation carved by the Colorado River.

fields.content: A condition named for this quantity is also called the admissibility condition for the Rankine–Hugoniot equations and is violated by rarefaction shock waves. The rate of production of this quantity per unit volume times absolute temperature is called the dissipation, whose non-zero value results in "lost work." While this quantity is macroscopically a monotonic function, it does not change in a microscopically reversible process. It is equal to Boltzmann's constant times the natural log of the number of microstates. For 10 points, name this quantity that always increases in a closed system according to the second law of thermodynamics, the measure of disorder in a system.

fields.content: This quantity was influenced by Carnot’s views on heat, based on the early 18th-century hypothesis that both heat and light were indestructible forms of matter. Count Rumford's 1789 demonstration that heat could be produced by friction also shaped our understanding of this quantity. Scientists like Ludwig Boltzmann, Josiah Willard Gibbs, and James Clerk Maxwell provided a statistical basis for it, involving the probability density of microstates in the Boltzmann distribution. These proofs identify the thermodynamic internal energy as the ensemble average in relation to this quantity. For 10 points, name this quantity for which, in cases of thermal equilibrium, the density matrix formulation is unnecessary if the basis states are chosen to be energy eigenstates.

wiki_sents: Carnot based his views of heat partially on the early 18th-century "Newtonian hypothesis" that both heat and light were types of indestructible forms of matter, which are attracted and repelled by other matter, and partially on the contemporary views of Count Rumford, who showed in 1789 that heat could be created by friction, as when cannon bores are machined.

These proofs are based on the probability density of microstates of the generalized Boltzmann distribution and the identification of the thermodynamic internal energy as the ensemble average U=\left\langle E_{i}\right\rangle .
This density matrix formulation is not needed in cases of thermal equilibrium so long as the basis states are chosen to be energy eigenstates.
Later, scientists such as Ludwig Boltzmann, Josiah Willard Gibbs, and James Clerk Maxwell gave entropy a statistical basis.
The state function was called the internal energy, that is central to the first law of thermodynamics.

fields.content: For this concept, the generalized Boltzmann principle applies, stated as "multiplicity equals the exponent of a certain measure." In Shannon's theory, this concept measures the average information content from a random variable. In thermodynamics, this is central to the second law, declaring that isolated systems evolve towards maximum disorder. Clausius originally formulated this principle, which indicates the direction of spontaneous processes. For 10 points, name this concept that quantifies the amount of disorder or randomness in a system, often measured in joules per kelvin.

fields.content: In a monologue written by this playwright, a man says he wants to "build that shed out in the garden" before finding the man who committed him, at age 16, to a mental hospital where the head doctor electrocuted him with pincers. fields.content: In June 2006, the British Academy of Film and Television Arts hosted a celebration of this author's films curated by his friend, the playwright David Hare. In a review published in 1958, the critic Irving Wardle coined the term "comedy of menace" to describe this author's early plays, borrowing from the subtitle of The Lunatic View: A Comedy of Menace. Actors who frequently collaborated with this writer include Alan Bates, who originated roles in The Caretaker and portrayed characters in Victoria Station and One for the Road. This author wrote The Birthday Party and explored themes of menace and isolation in works such as The Room and The Dumb Waiter. For 10 points, name this Nobel Prize-winning British playwright.

wiki_sents: In June 2006, the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) hosted a celebration of Pinter's films curated by his friend, the playwright David Hare.

In a review published in 1958, borrowing from the subtitle of The Lunatic View: A Comedy of Menace, a play by David Campton, critic Irving Wardle called Pinter's early plays "comedy of menace"—a label that people have applied repeatedly to his work.Merritt, Pinter in Play 5, 9, 225–26, and 310.

Several of those productions starred Alan Bates (1934–2003), who originated the stage and screen roles of not only Butley but also Mick in Pinter's first major commercial success, The Caretaker (stage, 1960; film, 1964); and in Pinter's double-bill produced at the Lyric Hammersmith in 1984, he played Nicolas in One for the Road and the cab driver in Victoria Station.
Later Pinter continued to campaign against the Iraq War and on behalf of other political causes that he supported.
Plays: One | The Birthday Party, The Room, The Dumb Waiter, A Slight Ache, The Hothouse, A Night Out.

fields.content: The reason why this statement does not apply to clock rates is given by a formula relating linear dimensions to power rates, Dennard scaling. This statement was formulated after Carver Mead had a discussion about the possibility that electron tunneling would limit the overall power of circuits. This statement is named after a man who once theorized that the cost of creating fabrication plants grows exponentially, and who founded Intel with Robert Noyce. fields.content: Prior to the adoption of this observation, excimer lasers had primarily been utilized as research devices since their development in the 1970s. In 2012, a team in MIT's Microsystems Technology Laboratories developed a twenty-two nanometer transistor based on InGaAs, the smallest non-silicon transistor ever built at the time, as part of efforts related to this observation. Characteristics of modern nanoscale transistors, such as multi-gate MOSFETs and the prevalent FinFET design, have evolved to align with this prediction. While the cost of computer power to the consumer falls, the cost for producers to fulfill this observation rises, with increasing R&D, manufacturing, and test costs for each new generation of chips. For 10 points, name this trend predicted by Gordon Moore in 1965, stating the number of transistors on a microchip would double approximately every two years.
clue_list: Prior to the adoption of this observation, excimer lasers had primarily been utilized as research devices since their development in the 1970s.

Characteristics of modern nanoscale transistors, such as multi-gate MOSFETs and the prevalent FinFET design, have evolved to align with this prediction.
While the cost of computer power to the consumer falls, the cost for producers to fulfill this observation rises, with increasing R&D, manufacturing, and test costs for each new generation of chips.
For 10 points, name this trend predicted by Gordon Moore in 1965, stating the number of transistors on a microchip would double approximately every two years.
wiki_sents: Prior to this, excimer lasers had been mainly used as research devices since their development in the 1970s.Basov, N. G. et al., Zh.
In 2012, a team in MIT's Microsystems Technology Laboratories developed a 22 nm transistor based on InGaAs which, at the time, was the smallest non-silicon transistor ever built.
Modern nanoscale transistors typically take the form of multi-gate MOSFETs, with the FinFET being the most common nanoscale transistor.

As the cost of computer power to the consumer falls, the cost for producers to fulfill Moore's law follows an opposite trend: R&D, manufacturing, and test costs have increased steadily with each new generation of chips.
Also due to Dennard scaling, this increased performance would not be accompanied by increased power, i.e., the energy-efficiency of silicon-based computer chips roughly doubles every 18 months.

fields.content: This concept is in the title of a Carol Stack book that explains how poor African-American inhabitants of "the Flats" relied on an "essential" type of this concept for stability. David Schneider emphasized the possibility of relationships of this type that are neither affinal nor consanguineal in a book on the "American" kind of this concept. Omaha, Crow, and Hawaiian systems of this concept are among those identified by Lewis Hunt Morgan. "Fictive" types of this concept include godparenthood, and systems of this concept can be distinguished by features like whether they have different terms for maternal and paternal aunts and uncles. fields.content: One explanation for this concept is that it lacks clear boundaries and is uniquely centered for each individual. Like Schneider, other anthropologists have largely rejected sociobiological accounts of human social patterns as reductionistic and empirically incompatible with ethnographic data on human social structures. Schneider's critique is recognized as a significant turning point in anthropology's study of social relationships related to this term. Regular marriages following prescriptive rules link lineages into fixed relationships, forming potential political alliances in societies influenced by this concept. Schneider's critique is widely acknowledged to have marked a turning point in anthropology's study of social relationships and interactions.

Insofar as regular marriages following prescriptive rules occur, lineages are linked together in fixed relationships; these ties between lineages may form political alliances in kinship dominated societies.

fields.content: This scientist received a £70 scholarship but found it insufficient to cover living and study expenses at Cambridge. He developed a general theory of the quantum field with dynamical constraints, foundational to gauge and superstring theories. In this context, he incorporated the work of Werner Heisenberg on matrix mechanics and Erwin Schrödinger on wave mechanics into a unified formalism associating measurable quantities to operators on the Hilbert space. wiki_sents: He passed and was awarded a £70 scholarship, but this fell short of the amount of money required to live and study at Cambridge.

He also developed a general theory of the quantum field with dynamical constraints, which forms the basis of the gauge theories and superstring theories of today.Misha, S., Quantum Field Theory II (Singapore: World Scientific, 2019), p. 287.

In that book, Dirac incorporated the previous work of Werner Heisenberg on matrix mechanics and of Erwin Schrödinger on wave mechanics into a single mathematical formalism that associates measurable quantities to operators acting on the Hilbert space of vectors that describe the state of a physical system.
Dirac established the most general theory of quantum mechanics and discovered the relativistic equation for the electron, which now bears his name.

fields.content: The effects of this condition are described in a pioneering patient narrative by German humanist Ulrich von Hutten. The Fugger family imported guaiacum wood from Hispaniola for the treatment of this condition, a method the alchemist Paracelsus opposed in favor of the use of mercury. Mercenaries afflicted with this condition were unable to fight in the Battle of Fornovo after spreading it to Naples during King Charles VIII's Italian campaign, beginning its common association with France. Along with maize and potatoes, this disease is one of the species usually thought to have been brought to the Old World via the Columbian Exchange. fields.content: In many countries, including Canada, the European Union, and the United States, this disease is a notifiable condition. Measures to increase access to testing appear effective at reducing rates of congenital manifestation of this disease in low- to middle-income countries. In October 2010, the U.S. formally apologized to Guatemala for the ethical violations related to this disease. In secondary stages of this disease, a diffuse rash often manifests, particularly affecting the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. For 10 points, name this sexually transmitted disease that became more manageable during the 20th century due to advancements in microbiology and pharmacology, caused by Treponema pallidum.

wiki_sents: Syphilis is a notifiable disease in many countries, including Canada, the European Union, and the United States.
Several measures to increase access to testing appear effective at reducing rates of congenital syphilis in low- to middle-income countries.
In October 2010, the U.S. formally apologized to Guatemala for the ethical violations that took place.
In secondary syphilis, a diffuse rash occurs, which frequently involves the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.

During the 20th century, as both microbiology and pharmacology advanced greatly, syphilis, like many other infectious diseases, became more of a manageable burden than a scary and disfiguring mystery, at least in developed countries among those people who could afford to pay for timely diagnosis and treatment.
fields.answer: syphilis [accept French disease before "France"] <Brownstein, History - European>

fields.content: Notable in some poems by this author is the use of floral and fragrant imagery to evoke nostalgia and past intimacy, often incorporating sensory details to create rich, vivid experiences. In the early 1860s, this poet accompanied Manet on daily sketching trips and met him socially. This French author viewed Edgar Allan Poe as a precursor and aimed to be his French counterpart. In *Les Fleurs du mal*, Walter Benjamin states that "the specific devaluation of the world of things, as manifested in the commodity, is the foundation of this French author's allegorical intention." Gustave Flaubert praised him by saying, "You have found a way to rejuvenate Romanticism… You are as unyielding as marble, and as penetrating as an English mist," after his own recent acquittal over *Madame Bovary*. The use of sound to create atmosphere and "symbols" in his poetry was further developed by Symbolists Verlaine and Mallarmé, who regard this author as a pioneer. wiki_sents: Notable in some poems is Baudelaire's use of imagery of the sense of smell and of fragrances, which is used to evoke feelings of nostalgia and past intimacy.Richardson 1994, p. 231.
In the early 1860s, Baudelaire accompanied Manet on daily sketching trips and often met him socially.
Baudelaire saw in Poe a precursor and tried to be his French contemporary counterpart.Richardson 1994, p. 140.
He says that, in Les Fleurs du mal, "the specific devaluation of the world of things, as manifested in the commodity, is the foundation of Baudelaire's allegorical intention."

Gustave Flaubert, recently attacked in a similar fashion for Madame Bovary (and acquitted), was impressed and wrote to Baudelaire: "You have found a way to rejuvenate Romanticism...You are as unyielding as marble, and as penetrating as an English mist.

Formally, the use of sound to create atmosphere, and of "symbols" (images that take on an expanded function within the poem), betray a move towards considering the poem as a self-referential object, an idea further developed by the Symbolists Verlaine and Mallarmé, who acknowledge Baudelaire as a pioneer in this regard.

fields.content: In March 2010, a mock trial of Henry V for the slaughter of prisoners during this battle was held in Washington, D.C., drawing from both historical records and Shakespeare's play. On the morning of October 25, the French awaited additional troops before this battle. Due to limited space, the French organized a third formation known as the rearguard, consisting primarily of varlets mounted on the horses of men fighting on foot at the front. Despite advancing through what the French monk of Saint Denis described as "a terrifying hail of arrow shot," the French men-at-arms' plate armour allowed them to close the distance to the English lines after the English longbowmen started shooting from extreme longbow range. In a play, Henry V delivers the famous St. Crispin's Day Speech to his soldiers just before this battle, urging his "band of brothers" to stand together in the forthcoming fight. thumb|John GilbertThe Morning of the Battle of Agincourt (1884), Guildhall Art Gallery On the morning of 25 October, the French were still waiting for additional troops to arrive.

On account of the lack of space, the French drew up a third battle, the rearguard, which was on horseback and mainly comprised the varlets mounted on the horses belonging to the men fighting on foot ahead.

Despite advancing through what the French monk of Saint Denis described as "a terrifying hail of arrow shot", the plate armour of the French men-at-arms allowed them to close the distance to the English lines after the English longbowmen started shooting from extreme longbow range (approximately ).

The play introduced the famous St Crispin's Day Speech, considered one of Shakespeare's most heroic speeches, which Henry delivers movingly to his soldiers just before the battle, urging his "band of brothers" to stand together in the forthcoming fight.

Keegan also speculated that due to the relatively low number of archers actually involved in killing the French knights (roughly 200 by his estimate), together with the refusal of the English knights to assist in a duty they saw as distastefully unchivalrous, and combined with the sheer difficulty of killing such a large number of prisoners in such a short space of time, the actual number of French prisoners put to death may not have been substantial before the French reserves fled the field and Henry rescinded the order.

fields.content: Alfred-Marie Liénard derived a nastily complex relativistic formula for this quantity in electromagnetism involving the square of the cross product of beta with the time derivative of beta. The value of this quantity for an accelerating point charge is proportional to charge squared times acceleration squared according to the Larmor formula, which is derived by noting that this quantity equals the flux of the Poynting vector through a surface. According to HUD's 2022 Annual Homeless Assessment Report, there were an estimated 2,560 homeless people in New Mexico.

New Mexico hosts 23 federally recognized tribal reservations, including part of the Navajo Nation, the largest and most populous tribe; of these, 11 hold off-reservation trust lands elsewhere in the state.
Several municipalities impose an Economic Development Gross receipts tax (a form of Municipal Infrastructure GRT) to pay for these infrastructure improvements and for marketing their areas.

Like other states in the American Southwest, New Mexico bears the legacy of the "Old West" period of American westward expansion, characterized by cattle ranching, cowboys, pioneers, the Santa Fe Trail, and conflicts among and between settlers and Native Americans.
Its poverty rate of roughly 18% is among the highest in the country, exceeded only by Louisiana and Mississippi.

Celebrated for its rich heritage, the annual ballooning event held here in October is the largest in the world. fields.content: These materials expand rather than contract when they crystallize. One important aspect of their mechanical strength is the study of dislocations.
