fields.content: Believed to be one of Shakespeare's earlier works, this play is preceded only by the three parts of Henry the Sixth and possibly Titus Andronicus, as well as a few comedies. In this play, Henry Tudor, the Earl of Richmond who later becomes King Henry the Seventh, is supported by figures such as his stepfather Lord Stanley, the Earl of Derby, along with the Earl of Oxford, Sir Walter Herbert, Sir James Blunt, and Sir William Brandon. It was once thought that the Quarto version represented a separate revision of this play by Shakespeare. Influenced by the "Tudor Myth" and emerging theologies of divine intervention and human agency, this play aims to depict Richard as divine retribution for the usurpation of Richard the Second. My kingdom for a horse!"

wiki_sents: Richard III is believed to be one of Shakespeare's earlier plays, preceded only by the three parts of Henry VI and perhaps Titus Andronicus and a handful of comedies.

Henry Tudor, Earl of Richmond – Henry VI's nephew; later King Henry VII Lord Stanley, Earl of Derby – Richmond's stepfather Earl of Oxford Sir Walter Herbert Sir James Blunt Sir William Brandon – Richmond's standard-bearer (non-speaking role)
At one time, it was thought that the Quarto represented a separate revision of the play by Shakespeare.

Thus it seems possible that Shakespeare, in conforming to the growing "Tudor Myth" of the day, as well as taking into account new theologies of divine action and human will becoming popular in the wake of the Protestant Reformation, sought to paint Richard as the final curse of God on England in punishment for the deposition of Richard II in 1399.
Richard has his eye on Elizabeth of York, Edward IV's next remaining heir, and poisons Lady Anne so he can be free to woo the princess.
Retrieved 23 June 2023 The phrase illustrates the drama and desperation of his sudden fall from grace and has entered common parlance as such.

The Quran does not specify the types of wealth to be taxed or the exact percentage to be given. Some scholars argue that the wealth of children and individuals with mental impairments should be taxed, while others disagree. Interpretations and applications of this practice vary across different Islamic sects. fields.content: In a polemic against these people, Isocrates criticized them for claiming art could be created through simple rules. fields.content: One work by a member of this group is considered one of the earliest uses of the “Antilogies,” or contradictory arguments, known as Dissoi Logoi. A student associated with this group allegedly taught that a person could argue for the weaker side of an argument being the stronger one, reflecting his mentor's skill in rhetoric. The aviation industry is able to perform most routine aircraft maintenance, except for heavy structural repairs.

fields.content: Archaeological evidence indicates that the Founding of Rome resulted from a prolonged development process, with definitive occupation occurring by the middle of the Bronze Age. According to legend, the twin brothers Romulus and Remus were central to this event. During this time, Faustulus reveals the brothers' true origins, leading them to depose Amulius and restore Numitor to his throne. Afterward, the brothers argue over the future city's location, resulting in Romulus killing Remus. Scholars consider the introduction of a line of Alban kings linking Romulus to Aeneas and the time of the Trojan War, thereby chronologically connecting Romulus to this legendary event, to be spurious. For 10 points, name this event, traditionally dated by historical writings to 753 BC.

Faustulus eventually reveals the brothers' true origins, and they depose or murder Amulius and restore Numitor to his throne.
Romulus was later chronologically connected to Aeneas and the time of the Trojan War by introducing a line of Alban kings, which scholars consider to be entirely spurious.

fields.content: A city inhabited by these people produced so much papyrus that the Greek word for papyrus derives from it. A writer named Philo compiled a lost history of these people. Herodotus visited a "temple of Heracles" built by these people which contained a gold pillar next to an emerald one dedicated to their god, Melqart. A profitable export developed by these people was extracted from murex sea snails. A capital of these people that had been captured by the Achaemenians was seized in 332 BCE after a causeway was built by Alexander the Great. fields.content: Due to the lack of indigenous written records, this civilization was long considered obscure, and only since the mid-20th century have historians and archaeologists uncovered its complexity and influence. One of the first areas to be conquered by Alexander the Great during his western Asia campaigns was home to this civilization. It remained a core asset to the Achaemenid Empire, particularly for their maritime technology and navigation, furnishing the bulk of the Persian fleet during the Greco-Persian Wars in the late fifth century BC. The Late Iron Age saw the height of their shipping, mercantile, and cultural activity, especially between 750 and 650 BC. They likely found the earliest and most profitable source of wealth in timber, which was scarce in Egypt and Mesopotamia. Their expansive trade network is credited with laying the foundations of an economically and culturally cohesive Mediterranean, later continued by the Greeks and Romans. For 10 points, name this civilization that cast figurines and fragments into the sea to ensure safe travels.

wiki_sents: The Phoenicians were long considered a lost civilization due to the lack of indigenous written records, and only since the mid-20th century have historians and archaeologists been able to reveal a complex and influential civilization.
Phoenicia was one of the first areas to be conquered by Alexander the Great during his military campaigns across western Asia.

The Phoenicians remained a core asset to the Achaemenid Empire, particularly for their prowess in maritime technology and navigation; they furnished the bulk of the Persian fleet during the Greco-Persian Wars of the late fifth century BC.
The Late Iron Age saw the height of Phoenician shipping, mercantile, and cultural activity, particularly between 750 and 650 BC.
Timber was probably the earliest and most lucrative source of wealth; neither Egypt nor Mesopotamia had adequate wood sources.

Their expansive and enduring trade network is credited with laying the foundations of an economically and culturally cohesive Mediterranean, which would be continued by the Greeks and especially the Romans.
Hundreds of figurines and fragments have been recovered from the Mediterranean, often spanning centuries between them, suggesting they were cast into the sea to ensure safe travels.

The Ahiram sarcophagus found in Byblos contains one of the earliest known inscriptions in their alphabet. This civilization's principal deities included the god of the sea, Yamm, and the goddess of fertility, Astarte. This ancient Semitic-speaking people were renowned for their production of a valuable purple dye extracted from the Murex snail. Their influence extended across the Mediterranean, leading to the establishment of powerful city-states such as Sidon and Tyre. One of their most famous colonies became a major power in the Western Mediterranean and was once led by the famous general Hannibal. For 10 points, identify these ancient people known for their seafaring and trade.

fields.content: This scientist is often credited with devising a problem in which a customer either stays in a waiting room or tries to wake up the namesake person if no one else is getting a haircut. That "sleeping barber" problem can be solved by "incrementing" and "decrementing" a special kind of variable this scientist developed that guarantees mutual exclusion and protects against race conditions. This creator of semaphores made an algorithm which is essentially a version of the A-star algorithm in which the heuristic function is set to zero; that algorithm named for this scientist only works if the edge weights of its input graph are non-negative. fields.content: In 1990, on the occasion of this computer scientist's sixtieth birthday, the Department of Computer Science at the University of Texas at Austin organized a two-day seminar in his honor. Initially dedicated to physics while working in Leiden, he envisioned a company, Mathematics, Inc., to commercialize the production of mathematical theorems. Known for pausing during lectures for reflection, he gained a reputation as a quick and deep thinker. For 10 points, name this computer scientist.

wiki_sents: In 1990, on occasion of Dijkstra's 60th birthday, the Department of Computer Science (UTCS) at the University of Texas at Austin organized a two-day seminar in his honor.
Dijkstra remained committed to physics for some time, working on it in Leiden three days out of each week.

The company was called Mathematics, Inc., a company that he imagined having commercialized the production of mathematical theorems in the same way that software companies had commercialized the production of computer programs.
However the pauses also served as a way for him to think on his feet and he was regarded as a quick and deep thinker while engaged in the act of lecturing.

fields.content: This city's airport is located within the UNESCO-recognized Parco naturale lombardo della Valle del Ticino. Empress Maria Theresa of Austria renovated this city extensively in the 18th century. In the 1950s and 60s, it became a major industrial hub and a center of design and architecture in Europe. IT companies like Google, Microsoft, and Yahoo! have established operations here. Louis of Orléans noted that much of Italy, including this city, was poorly defended, leading to its frequent selection for religious gatherings. In 2014, the City Council's approval of a new mosque caused political debate, especially from the Northern League. For 10 points, name this Italian city where Benito Mussolini's fascist Blackshirts rallied in Piazza San Sepolcro and initiated the March on Rome on October 28, 1922.

Empress Maria Theresa of Austria was responsible for the significant renovations carried out in Milan during the 18th century.
In the 1950s and 60s, as the main industrial centre of Italy and one of Europe's most dynamic cities, Milan became a world capital of design and architecture.
Milan has also seen a rapid increase in the presence of IT companies, with both domestic and international companies such as Altavista, Google, Italtel, Lycos, Microsoft, Virgilio and Yahoo!
The king's cousin, Louis of Orléans, took part in the expedition and realized most of Italy was virtually defenseless.
For this reason, it was used for religious gatherings, especially in particular celebratory moments.
In 2014 the City Council agreed on the construction of a new mosque amid bitter political debate, since it is strenuously opposed by right-wing parties such as the Northern League.

It was in Milan that Benito Mussolini built his political and journalistic careers, and his fascist Blackshirts rallied for the first time in the city's Piazza San Sepolcro; here the future Fascist dictator launched his March on Rome on 28 October 1922.
fields.answer: Milan, Lombardy, Italy [or Milano] <Bentley, Arts - Misc>

fields.content: This city is the setting for an opera by a composer who resisted Austrian rule, leading to a prison term at the Spilberg Castle. A prominent performance venue in this city was inaugurated with a production of "L'Europa riconosciuta" in 1778. The Biblioteca Ambrosiana, an important research library, was established here by Cardinal Federico Borromeo in 1602. This city's Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is one of the world's oldest active shopping galleries. A cathedral in this city is the largest in Italy and took nearly six centuries to complete. This city served as the capital of the Western Roman Empire starting in 286 AD. The Last Supper, a famous mural by Leonardo da Vinci, resides in this city's Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie. For 10 points, name this Italian city, renowned for fashion and home to a famous opera house.
clue_list: This city is the setting for an opera by a composer who resisted Austrian rule, leading to a prison term at the Spilberg Castle.
A prominent performance venue in this city was inaugurated with a production of "L'Europa riconosciuta" in 1778.
The Biblioteca Ambrosiana, an important research library, was established here by Cardinal Federico Borromeo in 1602.
This city's Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is one of the world's oldest active shopping galleries.
A cathedral in this city is the largest in Italy and took nearly six centuries to complete.
This city served as the capital of the Western Roman Empire starting in 286 AD. The Last Supper, a famous mural by Leonardo da Vinci, resides in this city's Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie.
For 10 points, name this Italian city, renowned for fashion and home to a famous opera house.
fields.answer: Milan, Lombardy, Italy [or Milano] <Bentley, Arts - Misc>

fields.content: Pausanias claimed that this man's tomb in Libethra was destroyed by a flood of the river Sys, and claimed that he committed suicide after visiting an oracle in a cave in Aornum . Some stories say that this native of Pimpleia inspired an oracle on Lesbos after his death, which may have been caused by women angered that he only took male lovers. He also may have been torn apart by Maenads , after which his head floated into the Mediterranean, still singing. While fleeing from Aristaeus , this man's wife was bitten by a snake. The Argonauts were protected from the Sirens by the efforts of this man, who fatally looked back on his way out of the underworld, thus losing his wife forever. For 10 points, name this husband of Eurydice , a mythological musician.

fields.content: This figure had a brother named Linus who became a Theban. According to Pausanias, in Laconia this Greek demigod introduced the worship of Demeter Chthonia. Euripides featured him in "Hypsipyle" during the Argonautic voyage, serving as coxswain and guardian of Jason's children. In Apollonius of Rhodes' "Argonautica," Jason, guided by Medea, is advised to follow the theme of not looking back, linked to this demigod. He is one of the few Greek heroes to undertake the nekyia, alongside Odysseus and Theseus. For 10 points, name this figure whose love for Eurydice is depicted in a play by Sarah Ruhl.

Jason, guided by Medea, is advised to follow the theme of not looking back, linked to this demigod.

wiki_sents: Orpheus had a brother named Linus, who went to Thebes and became a Theban.Apollodorus, Library and Epitome, 2.4.9.
In Laconia Orpheus is said to have brought the worship of Demeter ChthoniaPausanias, Laconia, 3.14.1,: "[…] but the wooden image of Thetis is guarded in secret.

"Euripides [also] brought Orpheus into his play Hypsipyle, which dealt with the Lemnian episode of the Argonautic voyage; Orpheus there acts as coxswain, and later as guardian in Thrace of Jason's children by Hypsipyle."

The myth theme of not looking back, an essential precaution in Jason's raising of chthonic Brimo Hekate under Medea's guidance,Apollonius of Rhodes, Argonautica, book III: "Let no footfall or barking of dogs cause you to turn around, lest you ruin everything", Medea warns Jason; after the dread rite, "The son of Aison was seized by fear, but even so he did not turn round..." (Richard Hunter, translator).
Orpheus was one of the handful of Greek heroesOthers to brave the nekyia were Odysseus, Theseus and Heracles; Perseus also overcame Medusa in a chthonic setting.
Ruhl removes Orpheus from the center of the story by pairing their romantic love with the paternal love of Eurydice's dead father.

fields.content: Jean Cocteau's 1949 film reimagines a character as a Parisian poet who communicates with the underworld through a radio set. Philip Glass composed an opera about this figure as part of his "Cocteau Trilogy," which includes films scored by Glass himself. fields.content: This novel contrasts the simplicity of seamen's yarns, the meaning of which "lies within the shell of a cracked nut," with the stories of a character for whom meaning was like a "misty halo." The protagonist of this novel becomes aware of a "flabby, pretending, weak-eyed devil" while watching a chain-gang walk up a hillside. In the frame story of this novel, its main character imagines a Roman soldier here at "the very end of the world" while looking out at the Thames from the deck of the Nellie. At the end of this novel, the narrator submits a report on the "Suppression of Savage Customs" after tearing off a postscriptum reading "exterminate all the brutes!" and lies to the Intended to conceal that a man's last words were "the horror! The horror!" For 10 points, name this novel in which Marlowe searches for Kurtz in the Congo by Joseph Conrad.

fields.content: In 2015, Jamie Lloyd and Laurence Bowen adapted Orson Welles' screenplay related to this novel for a BBC Radio Four broadcast. Ezra Pound advised T.S. Eliot against using a quotation from the climax of this novel as the epigraph for The Waste Land. E.D. Morel, a critic of King Leopold II's rule in the Congo, saw this work as a condemnation of colonial brutality. Adam Hochschild's King Leopold’s Ghost argues that scholars often focus on the novel’s psychological aspects, ignoring Joseph Conrad's depiction of the colonial atrocities in the Congo. For ten points, name this novel that features a frame story and is often contrasted with Chinua Achebe's Things Fall Apart.
clue_list: In 2015, Jamie Lloyd and Laurence Bowen adapted Orson Welles' screenplay related to this novel for a BBC Radio Four broadcast.

E.D. Morel, a critic of King Leopold II's rule in the Congo, saw this work as a condemnation of colonial brutality.
Adam Hochschild's King Leopold’s Ghost argues that scholars often focus on the novel’s psychological aspects, ignoring Joseph Conrad's depiction of the colonial atrocities in the Congo.

wiki_sents: In 2015, an adaptation of Welles' screenplay by Jamie Lloyd and Laurence Bowen aired on BBC Radio 4.
Eliot had planned to use a quotation from the climax of the tale as the epigraph for The Waste Land, but Ezra Pound advised against it.

Morel, who led international opposition to King Leopold II's rule in the Congo, saw Conrad's Heart of Darkness as a condemnation of colonial brutality and referred to the novella as "the most powerful thing written on the subject."

In King Leopold's Ghost (1998), Adam Hochschild wrote that literary scholars have made too much of the psychological aspects of Heart of Darkness, while paying scant attention to Conrad's accurate recounting of the horror arising from the methods and effects of colonialism in the Congo Free State.
In Things Fall Apart we see the effects of colonialism and Christian missionary endeavours on an Igbo community in West Africa through the eyes of that community's West African protagonists.

fields.content: This dynasty and its successor made the taotie motif, which depicts a hideous ogre. Its conquered land was ruled by Guanshu, Caishu , and Huoshu , three guards who instigated a namesake revolt against a duke shortly after this dynasty fell. In 1976, the relatively intact tomb of Fu Hao, a consort of one of this dynasty's rulers, was discovered. This dynasty, which was centered on the city of Anyang, lost power after its "immoral" King Zhou was defeated at the Battle of Muye . Tortoise shells and oxen scapulae were used by this dynasty to create oracle bones. Bronze pottery was produced by this dynasty, which succeeded the legendary Xia dynasty. For 10 points, name this first historically attested Chinese dynasty, which took control in the 18th century BC.

fields.content: David Nivison and Edward Shaughnessy argue for an end date of 1045 B.C. for this dynasty based on the Bamboo Annals. Besides their role as military commanders, rulers of this dynasty asserted social supremacy by acting as high priests and leading divination ceremonies. In the last century, Wang Guowei demonstrated that the succession of this dynasty's throne matched Sima Qian's Records of the Grand Historian. Despite grave robbers, the discovery of Tomb Five at Yinxu in 1976 revealed a richly furnished undisturbed tomb. This dynasty’s king maintained a thousand troops at the capital and led them into battle. Various bronze vessels were required for ceremonial purposes and religious divination. Tombs from this dynasty displayed highly ordered skeleton arrangements. For 10 points, name this dynasty that used oracle bones for divination, inscribed with early Chinese characters.

wiki_sents: David Nivison and Edward Shaughnessy argue for an end date of 1045 BC, based on their analysis of the Bamboo Annals.
Apart from their role as the head military commanders, Shang kings also asserted their social supremacy by acting as the high priests of society and leading the divination ceremonies.
In the last century, Wang Guowei demonstrated that the succession to the Shang throne matched the list of kings in Sima Qian's Records of the Grand Historian.

Many Shang royal tombs had been tunnelled into and ravaged by grave robbers in ancient times, but in the spring of 1976, the discovery of Tomb 5 at Yinxu revealed a tomb that was not only undisturbed, but one of the most richly furnished Shang tombs that archaeologists had yet come across.
The Shang king maintained a force of about a thousand troops at his capital and would personally lead this force into battle.
The Shang royal court and aristocrats required a vast number of different bronze vessels for various ceremonial purposes and events of religious divination.
Tombs displayed highly ordered arrangements of bones, with groups of skeletons laid out facing the same direction.
Evidence from excavations of the royal tombs indicates that royalty were buried with articles of value, presumably for use in the afterlife.

fields.content: A ruler during this period is said to have moved the capital to Yin, which marked the beginning of the second era in its chronology. Oracle bones inscribed with early Chinese characters were prominent during this time and were often used for divination practices. This era is noted for its bronze casting techniques, with impressive artifacts recovered from the ruins of its capital, Anyang. The discovery of Fu Hao's tomb, a consort and military leader, provided extensive insights into the social and cultural practices of the time. The Yellow River civilization flourished under this period, forming one of the cradles of Chinese civilization. This era preceded the Zhou dynasty and succeeded the semi-legendary Xia dynasty. It holds the distinction of being the first in Chinese history confirmed by archaeological evidence. For 10 points, identify this ancient Chinese dynasty known for its contributions to early Chinese writing and culture.

fields.content: A stuffed puma appears repeatedly in a novel by this author, including in a scene where the young protagonist convinces a dying professor that it's his dog. A character nicknamed "the Turk," who keeps his harelip covered with a handkerchief, falls in love with one of this author's protagonists, who uses dough to make fake grenades for guerrillas to use in a prison break. fields.content: From 1959 to 1965, this author worked with the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in Santiago, Brussels, and other locations in Europe. She spent months at Paula's bedside before learning that a hospital mishap had caused the brain damage. In 2011, she released El cuaderno de Maya , which alternates between settings in Berkeley, Chiloé, and Las Vegas. Known for a strict writing routine, she incorporates dreams, myths, and memories to create tales where reality and the fantastical intersect. Allende spent months at Paula's bedside before learning that a hospital mishap had caused the brain damage.

Allende also holds to a very strict writing routine.LATIN AMERICA'S SCHEHERAZADE; Drawing on dreams, myths, and memories, Chilean novelist Isabel Allende weaves fantastical tales in which reality and the absurd intersect.

Allende, whose works sometimes contain aspects of the genre magical realism, is known for novels such as The House of the Spirits (La casa de los espíritus, 1982) and City of the Beasts (La ciudad de las bestias, 2002), which have been commercially successful.

fields.content: One of these events is depicted on a grave marker decorated with a sun and a moon on one side and an army on the other, and is called the "doomsday stone." It is often wrongly claimed that Irish round towers were built due to these events, which led to the founding of Dublin as a longphort. The jeweled cover of an illuminated gospel book and the relics of St. Cuthbert were lost during one of these events. In order to stop these events from occurring in France, Charles the Simple offered Normandy to Rollo. fields.content: Over the subsequent 300 years, these events led to the unification of the Gaelic, Pictish, British, and English kingdoms, first into the Kingdom of Alba and eventually into the greater Kingdom of Scotland. In response, the Norse-Gaelic Kings of the Isles formed a defensive pact with the Kings of Scotland and Strathclyde in 973. Various factors, including demographic pressures, economic incentives, ideological motivations, political turmoil, technological advancements, and environmental changes, have been examined in the context of these incursions. Despite their scarcity and recognized biases, written sources about these invasions have been prioritized. Under Charlemagne, the Kingdom of the Franks faced significant challenges from these attacks, as the raiders could sail up the Seine with relative ease. fields.content: In 2012, a live radio play of this novel, adapted by Arthur Yorinks, was broadcast to mark its 75th anniversary. The protagonist Janie endures oppressive marriages to Logan Killicks, who treats her like a mule, and Joe Starks, who confines her to domesticity. She struggles to assert her identity, following orders without question. Bernard claims that cognition as "thinking, seeing, speaking, and knowing" is shaped by one's environment, a theme in this novel. For 10 points, name this novel where Janie's relationship with Vergible "Tea Cake" Woods, though volatile, finally provides her the loving marriage she desires.

wiki_sents: In 2012, a live radio play performance of Their Eyes Were Watching God, written by Arthur Yorinks, was recorded and broadcast to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the book's publication.Itzkoff, Dave, "Radio Play of 'Their Eyes Were Watching God' Is Set", The New York Times, February 8, 2012 (accessed March 25, 2012).
According to Bernard, cognition is the inner essence of an individual that embodies the idea of "thinking, seeing, speaking, and knowing", but is often determined by one's exterior environment.

During her first two marriages to Logan Killicks and Joe Starks, Janie is subjugated and held under their rule, the former comparing her to another mule to work his field and the latter keeping her in a powerless position of domesticity.
In her relationships, she is being ordered around by the man, but she did not question it, whether in the kitchen or bedroom.
While their relationship is volatile and sometimes violent, Janie finally has the loving marriage that she always wanted.
fields.answer: Their Eyes Were Watching God <Jose, Literature - American>
answer_accept: Their Eyes Were Watching God <Jose, Literature - American>

fields.content: Her work was once described by Alice Walker as representing a "triad of novels" that examine African-American women's roles in society, with this book often cited as the pinnacle. fields.content: In this composer's late Mass in E-flat major, the first eight bars of the Sanctus shift to B minor to G minor to E-flat minor. His longest symphony uses the three-key exposition "C major, E minor, G major," and two unison horns open it with the motto "long C, D, E, long A, short B, C." The 3/4-time first movement of a B minor symphony by this composer opens with an 8-bar introduction in the basses and cellos. Schumann praised the "heavenly length" of this composer's last symphony after Felix Mendelssohn premiered it after his death. An entr'acte from this composer's incidental music to Rosamunde may have been intended as the finale of that two-movement symphony. For 10 points, name this composer of the "Great" C major and "Unfinished" symphonies.

fields.content: This philosopher advocated the concept of pathei mathos, or understanding from suffering. He considered himself a reincarnation of Hermes and believed heavenly souls were trapped in a "body tomb". This thinker discovered the musical intervals of lyre strings and posited that heavenly bodies produced imperceptible tones based on their orbital periods. His followers abstained from eating both beans and flesh. One of his disciples threw himself into Mount Etna and was named Empedocles. He and his followers at Croton supposedly came up with a proof involving the square of a hypotenuse. For 10 points, name this pre-Socratic philosopher and namesake of a theorem regarding right triangles.

fields.content: According to legend, this Greek discovered that musical notes could be translated into mathematical equations after observing blacksmiths at work. Both Porphyry and Iamblichus report that this Greek persuaded a bull not to eat fava beans and convinced a destructive bear to vow not to harm living things. This Greek is also attributed with devising the doctrine of musica universalis, which suggests that the planets move according to mathematical equations, producing an inaudible symphony. Augustine of Hippo rejected this Greek's teaching of metempsychosis without naming him directly but otherwise expressed admiration for his work. He is credited with exploring the mathematical principles behind musica universalis. For 10 points, name this Greek who is most famous for the theorem stating that the square of the hypotenuse of a right triangle is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

wiki_sents: According to legend, Pythagoras discovered that musical notes could be translated into mathematical equations when he passed blacksmiths at work one day and heard the sound of their hammers clanging against the anvils.

Both Porphyry and Iamblichus report that Pythagoras once persuaded a bull not to eat fava beans and that he once convinced a notoriously destructive bear to swear that it would never harm a living thing again, and that the bear kept its word.
Augustine of Hippo (354–430 AD) rejected Pythagoras's teaching of metempsychosis without explicitly naming him, but otherwise expressed admiration for him.
He may have also devised the doctrine of musica universalis, which holds that the planets move according to mathematical equations and thus resonate to produce an inaudible symphony of music.
Pythagoras's biographers state that he also was the first to identify the five regular solids and that he was the first to discover the Theory of Proportions.
He believed in the Pythagorean doctrine of musica universalis and it was his search for the mathematical equations behind this doctrine that led to his discovery of the laws of planetary motion.

fields.content: This thinker established a secretive religious sect that believed in metempsychosis, or the transmigration of souls. He also devised a theory about the harmony of the spheres, which posits that celestial bodies produce a form of music as they move through the heavens. One of his doctrines claimed that everything could be explained in terms of whole numbers and their ratios. His followers, who adhered to strict rules including a prohibition on eating beans, were known as mathematikoi. Many of his teachings were passed down orally and are documented in fragments by later philosophers such as Iamblichus and Porphyry. This individual's influence is evident in the development of mathematical and philosophical thought. Who is this thinker?

fields.content: A narrative about two of these objects and a hidden marble are used in a psychological experiment devised by Simon Baron-Cohen to assess whether children attribute false beliefs to others. Papers published in 1939 and 1940 described experiments in which subjects were asked to choose between two of these objects with different characteristics by researchers Kenneth and Mamie Clark. These objects, which are central to the "Sally-Anne task," were used in research summarized by expert witnesses in the Brown v. Board case. Social learning theory was devised based on an experiment in which children imitated adults' actions toward one of these objects. For 10 points, what kind of object did adults beat up in Albert Bandura's experiment involving a "bobo" one?

fields.content: After approximately 10 minutes, the experimenter returned to the room, dismissed the adult model, and took the child into another playroom. Following exposure to their respective models, all three groups of children were then placed individually in a room with an experimenter. Researchers proposed that the novelty of the central object in the experiment could be a potential third variable that increases the probability of imitation by a child. fields.content: This man, whose "tongue is like no other," is put on trial in the jungle near San Cristobal in a George Steiner novel. Sebastian Haffner wrote a 1978 book titled for "the meaning of" this man. Unity Mitford left England specifically to seek out this man, whose alleged fascination with feces and repressed homosexuality are discussed in Walter Langer's psychological profile of him. The historian Hugh Trevor-Roper authenticated the diaries attributed to this man, which claimed that his secretary Martin Bormann was "indispensable" to his work. The book Grey Wolf claims that this man fled to Argentina, and was protected by the Peróns after he faked his death on April 30th, 1945. For 10 points, name this leader of Nazi Germany.

fields.content: This leader made his earliest known written statement about the Jewish question in a 16 September 1919 letter to Adolf Gemlich, now known as the Gemlich letter. His early eugenic policies targeted children with physical and developmental disabilities in a program called Action Brandt, and he later authorized a euthanasia program for adults with serious mental and physical disabilities, known as Aktion T4. He unsuccessfully attempted to maneuver the British into neutrality by offering them a non-aggression guarantee on 25 August; subsequently, he instructed Ribbentrop to present a last-minute peace plan with an impossibly short time limit in an effort to attribute the imminent war to British and Polish inactivity. One historian notes that "never in history has such ruination—physical and moral—been associated with the name of one man." In the final days of World War II, the Red Army surrounded Berlin by April 23, prompting Goebbels, a close associate of this leader, to issue a proclamation urging the city's residents to defend it. For 10 points, name this leader who considered the Sudeten issue unimportant, as his real intention was a war of conquest against Czechoslovakia.
clue_list: This leader made his earliest known written statement about the Jewish question in a 16 September 1919 letter to Adolf Gemlich, now known as the Gemlich letter.

His early eugenic policies targeted children with physical and developmental disabilities in a program called Action Brandt, and he later authorized a euthanasia program for adults with serious mental and physical disabilities, known as Aktion T4.

He unsuccessfully attempted to maneuver the British into neutrality by offering them a non-aggression guarantee on 25 August; subsequently, he instructed Ribbentrop to present a last-minute peace plan with an impossibly short time limit in an effort to attribute the imminent war to British and Polish inactivity.
One historian notes that "never in history has such ruination—physical and moral—been associated with the name of one man."

For 10 points, name this leader who considered the Sudeten issue unimportant, as his real intention was a war of conquest against Czechoslovakia.
wiki_sents: Hitler made his earliest known written statement about the Jewish question in a 16 September 1919 letter to Adolf Gemlich (now known as the Gemlich letter).

Hitler's early eugenic policies targeted children with physical and developmental disabilities in a programme dubbed Action Brandt, and he later authorised a euthanasia programme for adults with serious mental and physical disabilities, now referred to as .

Hitler unsuccessfully tried to manoeuvre the British into neutrality by offering them a non-aggression guarantee on 25 August; he then instructed Ribbentrop to present a last-minute peace plan with an impossibly short time limit in an effort to blame the imminent war on British and Polish inaction.
"Never in history has such ruination—physical and moral—been associated with the name of one man", he adds.
By 23 April, the Red Army had surrounded Berlin, and Goebbels made a proclamation urging its citizens to defend the city.
In private, Hitler considered the Sudeten issue unimportant; his real intention was a war of conquest against Czechoslovakia.
fields.answer: Adolf Hitler [prompt on A.H.] <Jose, Mixed/Other/General Knowledge>

fields.content: Beethoven wrote a F major concerto, Hess 12, for this instrument, although only sketches of the work survive, and the second movement was reconstructed in the late 20th century. The commonly accepted range for this instrument extends from B3 to about G6, covering over two and a half octaves, with a common tessitura from C4 to E6. Achieving a consistent sound on this instrument can be challenging due to the uniqueness of each reed. Commercial cane reeds for this instrument are available in various degrees of hardness, with medium reeds being particularly popular and medium-soft reeds often recommended for beginners. Mozart composed the solo concerto in C major, K. 314/285d, and the Sinfonia Concertante in E major, K. 297b, originally for this instrument, in addition to a fragment of an F major concerto, K. 417f. For 10 points, name this double-reed instrument that produces sound by blowing into the reed at sufficient air pressure, causing it to vibrate with the air column.

fields.content: This instrument originates from the shawm, a double-reed woodwind instrument used in medieval and Renaissance Europe. Supposedly first referred to as the "hautbois" by Michael Praetorius, it was extensively utilized by Jean-Baptiste Lully in the late 17th century for enhancing orchestral texture. Alessandro Marcello composed a concerto in D minor for this instrument, frequently misattributed to his brother Benedetto. This instrument starts the orchestra with a singular tuning note, usually an A. It is often the woodwind instrument played by Gabriel's ghost in the story "Gabriel's Oboe" from the film The Mission. For 10 points, name this double-reed instrument notable for its distinctive timbre.

fields.content: Napoleon Bonaparte esteemed this work as one of the notable pieces of European literature, having composed a Goethe-inspired soliloquy in his youth and carried this book on his campaign to Egypt. Despite the anguish it brings him, the protagonist spends several months fostering a close friendship with both of them. Werther endures significant embarrassment when he forgetfully visits a friend and unexpectedly encounters the entire aristocratic circle at a weekly gathering in this work. Johann Wolfgang von Goethe extensively revised this book for the 1787 edition and acknowledged the profound emotional impact it could have on despondent young lovers who encountered it. fields.content: Constructed by Mughal Emperor Jahangir in 1602, this object is located at the Diwan-i-Khas at the Agra Fort. "Pride of the Wolverines" (1926) "The Minnesota March" (1927) Dedicated to "The faculty and students of the University of Minnesota" "New Mexico March" (1928) "Salvation Army March" (1930) (dedicated to the Salvation Army's 50th anniversary in the U.S.) Sousa wrote marches for several American universities, including the University of Minnesota, University of Illinois, University of Nebraska, Kansas State University, Marquette University, Pennsylvania Military College (Widener University), and the University of Michigan.

Among Sousa's best-known marches are "The Stars and Stripes Forever" (National March of the United States of America), "Semper Fidelis" (official march of the United States Marine Corps), "The Liberty Bell", "The Thunderer", and "The Washington Post".

Musical accompaniment arose in the earliest dance, so that ancient Egyptians attributed the origin of the dance to the divine Athotus, who was said to have observed that music accompanying religious rituals caused participants to move rhythmically and to have brought these movements into proportional measure.

The movements and gestures of the choreography are primarily intended to mime the personality and aims of the characters and their part in the plot.Laban, Rudolf, The Mastery of Movement, MacDonald and Evans, London, 1960, p. 2 Such theatrical requirements tend towards longer, freer movements than those usual in non-narrative dance styles.
Research indicates that dancers do have greater difficulty controlling their eating habits as a large quantity strive for the art-form's ideal body mass.

fields.content: A little-known figure associated with this art form is Louis XIII, who once performed in a piece titled “Le Ballet de la Merlaison.” This activity includes a genre named after a region in Spain's Andalusia that features complex footwork and dramatic expressions, possibly influenced by Romani culture. In the late 19th century, Martha Graham revolutionized its contemporary form in New York City by emphasizing natural movement over rigid form. fields.content: Several of this author's students, such as Mukai Kyorai and Hattori Dohō, compiled quotations from him about their own poetry. Seeking seclusion, this writer moved to Fukagawa in the winter. Biographers have proposed various reasons and destinations for his travels, including an affair with a Shinto miko named Jacu, though this is unlikely. He introduced the term "haiku" to refer to the standalone five-seven-five form, considered the most artistic part of the haikai no renga. In Nihonbashi literary circles, his poetry was noted for its simple and natural style. For 10 points, name this poet known for works like "The Narrow Road to the Deep North."

wiki_sents: Several of his students compiled quotations from him about his own poetry, most notably Mukai Kyorai and Hattori Dohō.
That winter, he took the surprising step of moving across the river to Fukagawa, out of the public eye and towards a more reclusive life.
Biographers have proposed various reasons and destinations, including the possibility of an affair between Bashō and a Shinto miko named , which is unlikely to be true.
He invented the term haiku (replacing hokku) to refer to the freestanding 5–7–5 form which he considered the most artistic and desirable part of the haikai no renga.
In the fashionable literary circles of Nihonbashi, Bashō's poetry was quickly recognized for its simple and natural style.

The position of Bashō in Western eyes as the haiku poet par excellence gives great influence to his poetry: Western preference for haiku over more traditional forms such as tanka or renga have rendered archetypal status to Bashō as Japanese poet and haiku as Japanese poetry.

fields.content: One work by this author, which is sometimes translated as "Records of a Travel-Worn Satchel," captures his journey through the Tohoku region of Japan. This author’s association with the Danrin school initially influenced his writing style before he developed his own distinctive voice. He became renowned for perfecting a poetic form that consists of 17 syllables, structured in lines of 5-7-5. His poetic journey culminated in the travelogue "Narrow Road to the Deep North," considered a masterpiece of classical Japanese literature. This Edo-period poet's adoption of a simple yet profound style has been highly regarded for its aesthetic and philosophical depth. For 10 points, name this quintessential poet.

fields.content: A poem by this author suggests that humanity learned to "conform the order of their lives" by meditating in "groves," which are called "God's first temples." This author of "A Forest Hymn" wrote a poem whose imagery includes "where the rocking billows rise and sink / on the chafed ocean side." A poem by this writer speaks of God as a power who "from zone to zone," "guides through the boundless sky" the addressee's "certain flight." That poem by him asks the title bird, "whither… dost thou pursue thy solitary way?" in its first stanza. Another poem by this writer uses the images of "the innumerable caravan, who moves to that mysterious realm" and the "quarry-slave at night" to describe Death. fields.content: This author formerly owned land next to what is now the Nassau County Museum of Art in the Long Island village of Roslyn Harbor, New York, which is home to the William Cullen Bryant Preserve. This author and his friend Thomas Cole both considered the "geological structure" of Volterra in Italy at different times. This American poet published "The Ages," leading the volume titled Poems, arranged to publish on a trip to Harvard. He emerged as a significant poet in early literary America and has been grouped among the fireside poets for accessible and popular poetry. Under this writer's editorial leadership, the Post became a highly respected paper, serving as a major platform in the Northeast for the Democratic, Free Soil, and Republican Parties. For 10 points, name this writer who, in his final years, shifted from composing original poetry to producing a blank verse translation of Homer's works.

wiki_sents: Just outside New York City, the Long Island village of Roslyn Harbor, New York is home to the William Cullen Bryant Preserve, located on land he formerly owned next to what is now the Nassau County Museum of Art.
Thomas Cole was a friend and both, at different times, considered the "geological structure" of Volterra in Italy.
He also emerged as one of the most significant poets in early literary America and has been grouped among the fireside poets for his accessible and popular poetry.

Over the next half century, the Post would become the most respected paper in the city and, from the election of Andrew Jackson, the major platform in the Northeast for the Democratic Party and subsequently of the Free Soil and Republican Parties.
In his final years, Bryant shifted from writing his own poetry to a blank verse translation of Homer's works.
He subsequently published "The Ages", which led the volume and was titled Poems, which he arranged to publish on the same trip to Harvard.

fields.content: Emily Dickinson named this author as a literary influence in a letter to T.W. Higginson, despite her general disdain for contemporary poets. This author’s work was significantly shaped by his interest in botany, which is evident in his collection "The Fountain and Other Poems." He wrote several poems inspired by the landscapes and wilderness of New England, often delving into themes of nature and life cycles. He praised the "good gray poet" in a eulogy delivered at a centennial celebration. During his tenure as editor of the New York Evening Post, he supported the efforts of the abolitionist movement. fields.content: Georg Brandes, who began teaching Søren Kierkegaard's philosophy in the 1870s, wrote to this thinker asking him to read Kierkegaard, to which he replied that he would come to Copenhagen and read Kierkegaard with Brandes. This individual commented on the isolation he felt within the philological community and unsuccessfully attempted to transfer to a position in philosophy at Basel. wiki_sents: Brandes, who had started to teach the philosophy of Søren Kierkegaard in the 1870s, wrote to Nietzsche asking him to read Kierkegaard, to which Nietzsche replied that he would come to Copenhagen and read Kierkegaard with him.
Nietzsche remarked freely about the isolation he felt within the philological community and attempted unsuccessfully to transfer to a position in philosophy at Basel.
From 1888 through the 1890s there were more publications of Nietzsche works in Russia than in any other country.
At the core of his theory is a rejection of atomism—the idea that matter is composed of stable, indivisible units (atoms).
Only the fertile interplay of these two forces brought together as an art represented the best of Greek tragedy.

fields.content: A range of repressive measures, including the deportation of about twenty-five thousand people—mainly Yugoslavs—to concentration camps and elsewhere, occurred in this country between 1941 and 1943. One of the world's leading producers of renewable energy, this country ranked as the fourth largest provider of installed solar energy capacity and the sixth largest of wind power capacity in 2010. In 1348, the Black Death devastated this country, resulting in the death of possibly a third of its population, an event discussed by Stéphane Barry and Norbert Gualde in "The Biggest Epidemics of History." This country has the highest level of biodiversity of animal and plant species within the EU, with over fifty-seven thousand species recorded, representing more than a third of all European fauna. In this country, the prime minister and cabinet are appointed by the president and confirmed by a vote of confidence in parliament. After the Western Schism, the newly elected Pope Martin the Fifth returned to the Papal States and restored this country as the sole center of Western Christianity. Italy has probably the highest level of faunal biodiversity in Europe, with over 57,000 species recorded, representing more than a third of all European fauna, and the highest level of biodiversity of animal and plant species within the EU.

fields.content: Broadcast on radio by the BBC and with parts filmed and shown in cinemas, the coronation ceremony of George VI in 1937 marked a significant moment in British media history. Male sovereigns up to and including George VI have traditionally worn a crimson cap of maintenance for the opening procession and when seated in the Chair of Estate during the first part of the service. Although the offices of Lord High Steward and Lord High Constable have not been regularly filled since the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries respectively, they are revived for the coronation. Other members of the royal family, particularly queens consort, including dowagers, and UK princesses, wear distinctive purple velvet mantles edged with ermine over their court dresses. The organising committee decided that the entire event would be televised, except for the anointing and communion, which were also excluded from photography at the previous coronation. By the Tudor period, the hereditary post of Lord High Steward had merged with the Crown, and Henry VIII began the tradition of naming a temporary Steward for this ceremony, with separate commissioners for the court’s work. Although a monarch accedes to the throne upon their predecessor's death, the event is marked by the proclamation: "The king is dead, long live the king!" Stowe, a Connecticut-born woman of English descent, was part of the religious Beecher family and an active abolitionist.
In more recent years, his name has become an epithet directed towards African-Americans who are accused of selling out to whites.

To change the notion of manhood so that men could oppose slavery without jeopardizing their self-image or their standing in society, some abolitionists drew on principles of women's suffrage and Christianity as well as passivism, and praised men for cooperation, compassion, and civic spirit.

Comparsas are held throughout the week, consisting of large groups "of dancers dancing and traveling on the streets, followed by a Carrosa (carriage) where the musicians play.

Tobago's celebration culminates on Monday and Tuesday on a much smaller scale, however Tobago hosted its inaugural standalone carnival on October 28–30, 2022 Carnival combines costumes, dance, music, competitions, rum, and partying (fete-ing).
As Carnival coincides with summer in the Southern Hemisphere, in many parts of Argentina children play with water.

fields.content: The maximum depth of these regions is determined by the lower limit of karst processes, matching the base of soluble carbonate rocks. A month's pension and a blackletter Wycliffe Bible are traded for one of these things by a man who becomes obsessed with it. Another story describes highly sought-after ones called the Vindications, as well as Purifiers who destroy many of them. Examples of these things in that story include Axaxaxas mlö and The Combed Thunderclap, which are among the millions of them stored in hexagonal rooms. For 10 points, name these objects, the contents of "The Library of Babel."

fields.content: In this story, a library containing all possible books, arranged at random, effectively holds no usable information, as true data is indistinguishable from false. Websites have simulated this by generating screenfuls of random letters. The introductory quote, "By this art you may contemplate the variation of…," hints at the concept that an ensemble of all possible descriptions would, overall, hold zero information. Borges references Shakespeare indirectly, as the decipherable sentence "O time thy pyramids" comes from Sonnet 123. Each book in the library is marked by a coordinate indicating its specific location in the hexagonal structure. For 10 points, name this short story about a vast, incomprehensible library, written by Jorge Luis Borges.
clue_list: In this story, a library containing all possible books, arranged at random, effectively holds no usable information, as true data is indistinguishable from false.
Websites have simulated this by generating screenfuls of random letters.
The introductory quote, "By this art you may contemplate the variation of…," hints at the concept that an ensemble of all possible descriptions would, overall, hold zero information.
Borges references Shakespeare indirectly, as the decipherable sentence "O time thy pyramids" comes from Sonnet 123.
Each book in the library is marked by a coordinate indicating its specific location in the hexagonal structure.
For 10 points, name this short story about a vast, incomprehensible library, written by Jorge Luis Borges.
wiki_sents: In any case, a library containing all possible books, arranged at random, might as well be a library containing zero books, as any true information would be buried in, and rendered indistinguishable from, all possible forms of false information; the experience of opening to any page of any of the library's books has been simulated by websites which create screenfuls of random letters.See https://libraryofbabel.info/ The quote at the beginning of the story, "By this art you may contemplate the variation of the twenty-three letters," is from Robert Burton's 1621 The Anatomy of Melancholy.

Russell Standish's Theory of Nothing uses the concept of the Library of Babel to illustrate how an ultimate ensemble containing all possible descriptions would in sum contain zero information and would thus be the simplest possible explanation for the existence of the universe.

Borges makes an oblique reference to reproducing Shakespeare, as the only decipherable sentence in one of the books in the library, "O time thy pyramids", is surely taken from Shakespeare's Sonnet 123 which opens with the lines "No Time, thou shalt not boast that I do change, Thy pyramids...".

Each book is marked by a coordinate, corresponding to its place on the hexagonal library (hexagon name, wall number, shelf number, and book name) so that every book can be found at the same place every time.
The same would be true of protein sequences if it were not for natural selection, which has picked out only protein sequences that make sense.
He describes the Library of Mendel and the Library of Toshiba as subsets within the Library of Babel.
fields.answer: books [accept "The Book of Sand"; accept books in the Library of Babel after "Vindications"] <Grames, Literature - World>
answer_accept: books in the Library of Babel after "Vindications"

fields.content: The narrator of one story set in this location mentions a book inscribed with the words “Oh time thy pyramids” as an example of the arbitrariness found here. This location includes a vestibule at the entrance, which leads to hexagonal galleries containing walls of bookshelves. This setting’s layout is often compared to a "nonsensical" labyrinth, described by an anonymous cipher, and purportedly houses every possible combination of 410-page books. In this place, the books are written in an unspecified alphabetical order consisting of 25 orthographic symbols, including spaces, periods, and commas. fields.content: In a story from the Jataka, lightning destroys a hunter's house as punishment for killing three of these beings, namely Nandiya, Jollikin, and their starving mother. A Japanese folktale depicts one of them being revenge-killed by the children of a crab. One of these beings marries the widowed Tara after defeating his own brother to become the king of Kishkindha. A deity who resembled this animal was conceived when his mother ate divine cake sent by the wind god Vayu; that deity once once lifted an entire mountain while searching for an herb. Sugriva and other vanaras are generally depicted in the form of this animal, as was a deity who destroyed Lankapuri after Ravana's guards set his tail on fire. For 10 points, name this type of animal, whose form is taken by Hanuman.

fields.content: In some areas, these primates are regarded as agricultural pests and can damage crops significantly. Scientific classifications now favor monophyletic groups, including these animals. This group can be distinguished from other primates by having two pectoral nipples, a pendulous penis, and no sensory whiskers. After being socialized in human homes as infants, these primates undergo training before being placed with disabled individuals. They assist with daily tasks such as feeding, fetching, manipulating objects, and providing personal care. For 10 points, name these primates, which include members of both apes and the Cercopithecidae and Platyrrhini families.

wiki_sents: In some areas, some species of monkey are considered agricultural pests, and can cause extensive damage to commercial and subsistence crops.
Scientific classifications are now more often based on monophyletic groups, that is groups consisting of all the descendants of a common ancestor.
Monkeys, including apes, can be distinguished from other primates by having only two pectoral nipples, a pendulous penis, and a lack of sensory whiskers.
After being socialized in a human home as infants, the monkeys undergo extensive training before being placed with disabled people.
Apes are thus deep in the tree of extant and extinct monkeys, and any of the apes is distinctly closer related to the Cercopithecidae than the Platyrrhini are.
Around the house, the monkeys assist with daily tasks such as feeding, fetching, manipulating objects, and personal care.

fields.content: Removing three holes from one of these objects creates a topological surface called the "pair of pants." A Morin surface is formed by manipulating one of these objects, and David Hilbert illustrated that all geodesics on this structure are closed curves. The number of these objects that can touch another one of these objects is known as the kissing number. Johannes Kepler proposed a famous conjecture about the optimal packings for this structure in three-dimensional space. A coordinate system named after this object represents points as a distance, a polar angle, and an azimuthal angle. For 10 points, name this object that consists of all points in three-dimensional space that are equidistant to a given point.

The angle between two such objects at a real point of intersection is the dihedral angle from the tangent planes at that point. A parametric equation for these objects with radius r and center at uses trigonometric functions. At an umbilic, all sectional curvatures of these figures are equal. wiki_sents: In their book Geometry and the Imagination, David Hilbert and Stephan Cohn-Vossen describe eleven properties of the sphere and discuss whether these properties uniquely determine the sphere.
The angle between two spheres at a real point of intersection is the dihedral angle determined by the tangent planes to the spheres at that point.
A parametric equation for the sphere with radius r > 0 and center (x_0,y_0,z_0) can be parameterized using trigonometric functions.
At an umbilic all the sectional curvatures are equal; in particular the principal curvatures are equal.
Any rotation about a line through the origin can be expressed as a combination of rotations around the three-coordinate axis (see Euler angles).
These properties define the sphere uniquely and can be seen in soap bubbles: a soap bubble will enclose a fixed volume, and surface tension minimizes its surface area for that volume.

fields.content: The principle of an epicycloid, as modeled by Huygens, is closely linked to this geometric shape. Gabriel's horn paradoxically exhibits infinite surface area and a concept akin to this object. Archimedes demonstrated that the volume of this shape is two-thirds that of a circumscribed cylinder. This geometric figure appears in the Poincaré conjecture, a famous problem in topology proven by Grigori Perelman. The law of cosines is generalized for this shape when studying spherical trigonometry. For 10 points, name this three-dimensional shape.

fields.content: Scribner's encouraged publicity for this novel, allowing Ernest Hemingway to gain significant recognition, to the extent that his divorce from Richardson and marriage to Pfeiffer attracted media attention. Drawing on the Bible, Walt Whitman, and *Adventures of Huckleberry Finn*, this novel by Hemingway employs deliberate understatement and heavily incorporates parataxis. Hemingway scholar Zoe Trodd explains that the skeletal sentences in this novel were crafted in response to Henry James’s observation that World War I had “used up words,” and that Hemingway’s style in this novel is similar to a “multi-focal” photographic reality. According to Reynolds, this novel could have been written only circa 1925, as it effectively captures the period between World War I and the Great Depression, immortalizing a group of characters. Nagel writes that this work "was a dramatic literary event and its effects have not diminished over the years." In this novel, Hemingway employed techniques such as understatement, the removal of sentimentalism, and presenting images and scenes without explanatory context, culminating in a conclusion that leaves multiple future possibilities for Brett and Jake. For 10 points, name this book that features Jake, an expatriate American journalist living in Paris, and Brett, a twice-divorced Englishwoman with bobbed hair and numerous love affairs, who embodies the new sexual freedom of the 1920s.

wiki_sents: Scribner's encouraged the publicity and allowed Hemingway to "become a minor American phenomenon"—a celebrity to the point that his divorce from Richardson and marriage to Pfeiffer attracted media attention.Leff (1999), 63 Reynolds believes The Sun Also Rises could have been written only circa 1925: it perfectly captured the period between World War I and the Great Depression, and immortalized a group of characters.Reynolds (1990), 43 In the years since its publication, the novel has been criticized for its antisemitism, as expressed in the characterization of Robert Cohn.

Drawing on the Bible, Walt Whitman and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Hemingway wrote in deliberate understatement and he heavily incorporated parataxis, which in some cases almost becomes cinematic.Bloom (1987), 7–8 His skeletal sentences were crafted in response to Henry James's observation that World War I had "used up words," explains Hemingway scholar Zoe Trodd, who writes that his style is similar to a "multi-focal" photographic reality.

As a novice writer and journalist in Paris, Hemingway turned to Ezra Pound—who had a reputation as "an unofficial minister of culture who acted as mid-wife for new literary talent"—to mark and blue-ink his short stories.Meyers (1985), 70–74 From Pound, Hemingway learned to write in the modernist style: he used understatement, pared away sentimentalism, and presented images and scenes without explanations of meaning, most notably at the book's conclusion, in which multiple future possibilities are left for Brett and Jake.Wagner-Martin (1990), 2–4Hemingway wrote a fragment of an unpublished sequel in which he has Jake and Brett meeting in the Dingo Bar in Paris.

Hemingway scholar Linda Wagner-Martin writes that, in taking Fitzgerald's advice, Hemingway produced a novel without a central narrator: "Hemingway's book was a step ahead; it was the modernist novel.
Nagel writes that "The Sun Also Rises was a dramatic literary event and its effects have not diminished over the years.
He considered the bullring as war with precise rules, in contrast to the messiness of the real war that he, and by extension Jake, experienced.
Jake is an expatriate American journalist living in Paris, while Brett is a twice-divorced Englishwoman with bobbed hair and numerous love affairs, and embodies the new sexual freedom of the 1920s.

fields.content: These molecules typically exceed the size of lamellae, often around 10 nanometers. Common techniques for analyzing them include size-exclusion chromatography, or gel permeation chromatography, sometimes coupled with static light scattering to determine their number-average molecular weight, weight-average molecular weight, and dispersity. Molecules containing ionizable subunits, like pendant carboxylic groups, are termed polyelectrolytes or ionomers, depending on the fraction of ionizable units. These molecules usually form miscible solutions not due to favorable interactions but due to an increase in entropy and free energy. Crystallization and melting describe the phase transitions between their semi-crystalline and amorphous solid states. For 10 points, name these molecules, examples of which are commonly known by trivial names in consumer products.

The lamellae are much thinner than the polymers are long (often about 10 nm).Wolfgang Kaiser: Kunststoffchemie für Ingenieure.

Select common techniques include the following: Size-exclusion chromatography (also called gel permeation chromatography), sometimes coupled with static light scattering, can used to determine the number-average molecular weight, weight-average molecular weight, and dispersity.
A polymer containing ionizable subunits (e.g., pendant carboxylic groups) is known as a polyelectrolyte or ionomer, when the fraction of ionizable units is large or small respectively.
Many commonly used polymers, such as those found in consumer products, are referred to by a common or trivial name.

In other words, miscible materials usually form a solution not because their interaction with each other is more favorable than their self-interaction, but because of an increase in entropy and hence free energy associated with increasing the amount of volume available to each component.
Instead, crystallization and melting refer to the phase transitions between two solid states (i.e., semi-crystalline and amorphous).

fields.content: After an earthquake created a pit at this location, an oracle instructed citizens to fill it with "their greatest treasure"; a man named Marcus then hopped into the chasm at this location, so it was named the Lacus Curtius after him. Roman engineers calculated distance by using an umbilicus or navel at this location. The tribune Caius Licinius was said to have to been the first to "turn his back" to a group of people at this location while standing at the first rostra, which was built here. People in this place often viewed corpses hung nearby the Gemonian Stairs. The Arch of Septimius Severus and the Aemelia Basilica were additions to this location, which was originally lined with tabernae or shops. fields.content: Archaeological evidence suggests that by the end of the seventh century BCE, the ground level of the Roman Forum was raised in certain areas to improve drainage and establish a pebble-paved foundation. The earliest structures here were in two areas: the Comitium and sanctuaries including the Regia, the House of the Vestals, and the Domus Publica. During Sulla's dictatorship in the eighties BCE, the Forum underwent changes including the plaza level being raised by nearly a meter and the installation of permanent marble paving stones. The last major expansion of the Roman Forum occurred during Constantine the Great's reign, with the completion of the Basilica of Maxentius in 312 CE. After the fall of the Western Roman Empire and the Gothic Wars, the Forum, like much of Rome, fell into disrepair due to warfare, famine, and lack of central authority. For 10 points, name this ancient central area of Rome, where sediments from Tiber River flooding and hill erosion have gradually raised its floor level.
clue_list: Archaeological evidence suggests that by the end of the seventh century BCE, the ground level of the Roman Forum was raised in certain areas to improve drainage and establish a pebble-paved foundation.
The earliest structures here were in two areas: the Comitium and sanctuaries including the Regia, the House of the Vestals, and the Domus Publica.
During Sulla's dictatorship in the eighties BCE, the Forum underwent changes including the plaza level being raised by nearly a meter and the installation of permanent marble paving stones.

The last major expansion of the Roman Forum occurred during Constantine the Great's reign, with the completion of the Basilica of Maxentius in 312 CE. wiki_sents: Archaeological evidence shows that by the end of the 7th century BC, the ground level of the Forum was raised significantly in some places to overcome the problems of poor drainage and provide a foundation for a pebble-paved area.Ammerman, Albert J., 1990, “On the Origins of the Forum Romanum”, American Journal of Archaeology, Vol.

The earliest structures in the Forum were discovered in two separate locations: the site of the Comitium and the group of sanctuaries of Regia (House of the kings), House of the Vestals and Domus Publica.

In the 80s BC, during the dictatorship of Sulla, major work was done on the Forum including the raising of the plaza level by almost a meter and the laying of permanent marble paving stones.Connolly, Peter and Hazel Dodge (1998), The Ancient City: Life in Classical Athens & Rome, Oxford University Press, pp.
The reign of Constantine the Great saw the construction of the last major expansion of the Forum complex—the Basilica of Maxentius (312 AD).

After the Fall of the Western Roman Empire, and the resulting Gothic Wars between the Byzantine / Eastern Roman Empire and the Ostrogoths over Italia, much of the city of Rome fell into ruin, from famine, warfare, and lack of authority.
Because of its location, sediments from both the flooding of the Tiber and the erosion of the surrounding hills have been raising the level of the Forum floor for centuries.

fields.content: One of the largest examples of this structure was created in Moscow after the Palace of Soviets remained uncompleted. Ozone, an effective bactericide, is commonly used in this recreational structure’s circulation system with cartridge filtration, but not with sand media filtration due to clogging issues. There is no consensus on whether fencing is required, and in many rural areas, it is not. To prevent cracking from freezing, its plumbing is sealed with air, often using rubber plugs. For competition pools, it is typically indoors and heated for year-round use and easier compliance with regulations on temperature, lighting, and officiating equipment. Air bubbles may be introduced via an air-bleed venturi pump to cool the pool if the temperature rises too high. Bacteria and virus levels must be kept low to prevent diseases. Dedicated swimsuits are generally required as regular clothes can weigh a swimmer down. For 10 points, name this recreational facility known for peculiar and exciting activities.

wiki_sents: One of the largest swimming pools ever built was reputedly created in Moscow after the Palace of Soviets remained uncompleted.
Ozone is an effective bactericide and is commonly included in the circulation system with cartridge filtration, but not with sand media filtration due to clogging problems with turbid body fats.
There is no consensus between states or countries on the requirements to fence private swimming pools, and in many places they are not required at all, particularly in rural settings.
The plumbing is sealed with air, typically with rubber plugs, to prevent cracking from freezing water.

Competition pools are generally indoors and heated to enable their use all year round, and to more easily comply with the regulations regarding temperature, lighting, and automatic officiating equipment.
Air bubbles may be introduced into the nozzles via an air-bleed venturi pump that combines cooler air with the incoming heated water to cool the pool if the temperature rises uncomfortably high.
Levels of bacteria and viruses in swimming pool water must be kept low to prevent the spread of diseases and pathogens.
When finished, the water and air can be let out and this type of pool can be folded up for convenient storage.

For men, wearing ordinary shorts and a T-shirt to go in the water at a beach may be considered acceptable, but pools usually require real swimsuits or other dedicated water wear as swimming with regular clothes can potentially weigh a swimmer down should they need to be rescued.
fields.answer: swimming pools [accept The Swimming-Pool Library; accept library until read] <Bentley, Mixed/Other/General Knowledge>

fields.content: This structure can feature a scum gutter and surge tank, as recommended by the Model Aquatic Health Code. These often appear in early 20th-century American art deco resorts such as The Don CeSar. Modern sporting events held in them can utilize an Olympic-sized version, measuring 50 meters in length. They require regular maintenance, including pH and chlorine levels checks, to remain safe for recreational use. Variants of these structures can be found in community centers, hotels, or private homes. Water polo, synchronized swimming, and diving are competitive sports that take place within them. fields.content: This genre is characterized by a specific rhythmic effect that can be applied to any meter. The success of "All Coons Look Alike to Me" played a role in popularizing it, despite leading to derogatory "coon songs" due to their racist content. The introduction of its rhythms in early 20th-century dance culture inspired new dance steps popularized by Vernon and Irene Castle. Marvin Hamlisch's arrangement of Scott Joplin's 1902 rag "The Entertainer" won an Academy Award and reached number three on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1974. The most well-known recording from this genre is Pee Wee Hunt's version of Euday L. Bowman's "Twelfth Street Rag." For ten points, name this genre that served as a precursor to Stride piano, developed by black East Coast pianists such as James P. Johnson, Fats Waller, and Willie "The Lion" Smith.

wiki_sents: Ragtime is not a meter in the same way that marches are in duple meter and waltzes are in triple meter; it is rather a musical style that uses an effect that can be applied to any meter.
The most famous recording of this period is Pee Wee Hunt's version of Euday L. Bowman's "Twelfth Street Rag."
The new rhythms of ragtime changed the world of dance bands and led to new dance steps, popularized by the show-dancers Vernon and Irene Castle during the 1910s.

While the success of "All Coons Look Alike to Me" helped popularize the country to ragtime rhythms, its use of racial slurs created a number of derogatory imitation tunes, known as "coon songs" because of their use of racist and stereotypical images of black people.
Hamlisch's rendering of Joplin's 1902 rag "The Entertainer" won an Academy Award, and was an American Top 40 hit in 1974, reaching No.
Stride piano – a style of piano that emerged after World War I, developed by and dominated by black East-coast pianists (James P. Johnson, Fats Waller, and Willie 'The Lion' Smith).

fields.content: Adolf Grünbaum argues in *The Foundations of Psychoanalysis* that Karl Popper was mistaken and that many of this man's theories are empirically testable, a position supported by Hans Eysenck. In October 1885, this psychologist undertook a three-month fellowship in Paris to study under the renowned neurologist Jean-Martin Charcot, who was researching hypnosis. This man applied significant pressure on patients to "reproduce" scenes of infantile sexual abuse, which he believed were repressed into the unconscious. Morris Eagle criticizes the data derived from clinical situations for its epistemologically contaminated status, arguing that such data have questionable probative value for testing this man’s psychoanalytic hypotheses. For 10 points, name this man who developed a topographical model of the mind, emphasizing the systemic properties of the unconscious and writing extensively on dream interpretation.
clue_list: Adolf Grünbaum argues in *The Foundations of Psychoanalysis* that Karl Popper was mistaken and that many of this man's theories are empirically testable, a position supported by Hans Eysenck.

Morris Eagle criticizes the data derived from clinical situations for its epistemologically contaminated status, arguing that such data have questionable probative value for testing this man’s psychoanalytic hypotheses.
